THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Eileene Coleman, Respondent,
        v.
        Standard Insurance Company and The State Budget and Control Board, a political subdivision of 
          the State of South Carolina, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-127
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 7, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Michael T. Brittingham and James T. Hedgepath, both of Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
        Max T. Hyde, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court reversed the decision of the Long Term Disability Appeals Committee of the Employee Insurance Programs terminating Eileene Colemanâ€™s long-term disability (LTD) insurance benefits.Â  Standard Insurance Company and The State Budget and Control Board of South Carolina (Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
Coleman worked as a registered nurse manager for the South Carolina Department of Corrections.Â  Coleman had LTD insurance through the Stateâ€™s Long Term Disability Income Benefit Plan.Â  Standard Insurance Company is claims administrator of the Plan.Â  If a member becomes disabled while covered under the Plan, the member may receive LTD benefits.Â  To be eligible for benefits for the first two years of a disability, a member must meet the Planâ€™s â€œOwn Occupationâ€ definition of disability.Â  

  Own Occupation means any employment . . . that involves Material Duties of the same general character as your regular and ordinary employment with the Employer.Â  Your Own Occupation is not limited to your job with your Employer.Â  

In 2000, Doctor Byron Bailey diagnosed Coleman with â€œa right-sided disc herniation at C5-6â€ based on an MRI scan.Â  Coleman had a history of chronic neck pain before this diagnosis and, since at least 1993, took several medications for this pain, for hypertension, and for depression.Â  On August 7, 2000, Coleman had a â€œC5-6 anterior cervical diskectomy and fusionâ€ in an attempt to alleviate her pain.Â  As a result, Coleman applied for LTD benefits, which Appellants granted on November 20, 2000.[2]Â  
Over the next several months Colemanâ€™s condition improved though she still complained of some pain.Â  In July 2001, Coleman saw Doctor Ronald A. McIver, a pain specialist, for the first time.Â  Coleman complained of significant pain in her cervical spine and upper torso.Â  Coleman indicated she could not do her household chores or enjoy her hobbies of traveling and gardening.Â  
After some treatments from Dr. McIver, and even though Coleman reported her condition had improved and she was sleeping better, Dr. McIver performed a nerve root block procedure to help with the pain.Â  Coleman reported â€œexcellent reliefâ€ as a result of this procedure.Â  In early August, after Coleman returned from a five-day trip to Atlanta, she reported she â€œwas able to â€˜walk all over Atlanta.â€™â€Â  She then went on a ten-day camping trip to Michigan, and the evidence indicates she tolerated her medications well, and her condition continued to improve.Â  
Doctor Elias Dickerman, a consulting physician for Appellants, reviewed Colemanâ€™s file in the fall of 2001.Â  Dr. Dickerman noted Colemanâ€™s position as a nurse manager may qualify as a medium capacity position, requiring some heavier lifting, â€œonly because of the potential that she might need to handle inmates directly.â€Â  Based on his evaluation of Colemanâ€™s medical records, Dr. Dickerman concluded â€œthis patient can perform activities at the light capacity category with many activities up to the medium capacity category.â€Â  
Based on information related to Colemanâ€™s South Carolina Retirement System (SCRS) claim and a questionnaire completed by Dr. Bailey describing Colemanâ€™s physical capacities, Appellants determined that Coleman could perform the duties required by her job.[3]Â  Colemanâ€™s claim was closed with a transitional benefit of $2,500.Â  Coleman appealed that determination.
As part of the appeal process, Dr. William Stewart, a Clinical Associate Professor of Rehabilitation Counseling and Neuropsychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, reviewed Colemanâ€™s file.Â  He opined that Colemanâ€™s job involved medium capacity work, â€œwith the reasonable expectation that the job would, in fact, require heavy and even very heaving physical strength in emergency situations.â€Â  He noted that the classification of registered nurse manager as light work â€œis only intended as an average or guide in describing what a worker does/has to do physically. . . .â€Â  Finally, Dr. Stewart offered the following opinion after listing the medications Coleman took:Â  â€œI have worked with many workers over the years who would not be able to maintain adequate concentration and attention span to perform a skilled job such as Registered Nurse Manger/Director of Nursing while taking these medications.â€ 
Karol Paquette, a vocational case manager for Appellants, prepared a memorandum regarding Colemanâ€™s appeal package and indicated that the United States Department of Labor listed Colemanâ€™s occupation as sedentary.Â  Dr. Dickerman also reviewed Colemanâ€™s appeal and concluded her occupation should be categorized as sedentary.Â  He further noted that Coleman could perform the duties of a registered nurse manager and that there appeared to be no cognitive side effects from her medication. 
The decision to close Colemanâ€™s LTD claim was upheld by her caseworker, Appellantsâ€™ quality assurance unit, and by the appeals committee.Â  Coleman appealed to the circuit court, which reversed the committeeâ€™s decision.Â  The reversal was based largely on the conclusion Colemanâ€™s pain medication could impede her ability to function in her present occupation or a similar one.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue substantial evidence in the record supports the committeeâ€™s decision to close Colemanâ€™s LTD benefits on December 7, 2001, and, therefore, the circuit court misapplied its standard of review.Â  We agree.
Section 1-23-380(A) of the South Carolina Code (2005) provides for judicial review of the decision of a state agency.Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) and (f) provide that, upon judicial review of the decision of a state agency:

  [t]he court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm the decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are . . . (e) clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record; or (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Therefore, this court must affirm the findings of fact made by the committee if they are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Substantial evidence is that evidence which, in considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999); McGuffin v. Schlumberger-Sangamo, 307 S.C. 184, 186, 414 S.E.2d 162, 163 (1992).Â  When a conflict in the evidence exists, the findings of fact of the administrative agency are conclusive.Â  Glover v. Columbia Hosp. of Richland County, 236 S.C. 410, 418, 114 S.E.2d 565, 569 (1960).Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Tiller, 334 at 338-39, 513 S.E.2d at 845.
The research of Paquette and Dr. Dickerman supports the committeeâ€™s finding that Colemanâ€™s own occupation of nurse manager is sedentary in nature.Â  Likewise, Dr. Baileyâ€™s evaluation of Coleman, Colemanâ€™s SCRS testimony, and Dr. Dickermanâ€™s opinion on Colemanâ€™s limitations support the decision of the committee that Coleman is capable of performing sedentary to light work.Â  Finally, no evidence in the record indicates Coleman had cognitive difficulties as a result of her medication.Â  In fact, the substantial evidence in the record indicates Colemanâ€™s medicine was effective and well tolerated.Â  
As a result of the record presented to it, the committee closed Colemanâ€™s claim.Â  The committeeâ€™s decision emphasized Paquetteâ€™s vocational review, Dr. Dickermanâ€™s medical review, the notes of Bailey and McIver, and Colemanâ€™s testimony to the SCRS.Â  In contrast, the circuit courtâ€™s order emphasized Dr. Stewartâ€™s recommendations and comments, derived a different inference from Dr. McIverâ€™s notes, and weighed the other evidence differently than did the committee.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold the circuit court improperly applied its standard of review, and substantial evidence in the record supports the decision of the committee.Â  Therefore, the decision of the circuit court is
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The benefits became retroactively effective on August 28, 2000.Â  
[3] Following her surgery Coleman also applied for disability retirement with the SCRS.Â  At a hearing in 2001, Coleman testified she could regularly drive a car, maintain her home, and walk short distances, and believed she could return to work as a nurse practitioner.Â  Her application for disability retirement was denied.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        John Graham Heller, Jr., Respondent,
        v.
        Joyce McDonald Heller, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
Â John M. Rucker, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-128
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 7, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        H. Wesley Kirkland, Jr. and John S. Nichols, both of Columbia, for Appellant. 
        Donald Bruce Clark, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, Joyce Heller contends the family court erred in its distribution of marital property and in failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm as modified.Â  
FACTS
John Graham Heller (Husband) and Joyce McDonald Heller (Wife) married on November 26, 1989.Â  Both had adult children from previous relationships.Â  They separated on April 4, 2000 and Husband filed for divorce in July 2001.Â  During the marriage, Husband worked at Columbia Supply Company earning $5.30 per hour.Â  Wife was a teacher at Newberry High School for the first five years of the marriage.Â  She later resigned and did not work for two to three years until she obtained part-time employment with the census bureau.Â  She also taught summer school courses at Newberry College.Â  
During the marriage, the parties lived at 725 Caldwell Street in Newberry, South Carolina.Â  The marital home was titled in Wifeâ€™s name.Â  She acquired the home for $188,000 approximately a year and a half before the parties met.Â  This home sold shortly after the parties separated for a net gain of approximately $267,000. 
The parties also owned rental properties at 723 Caldwell Street and 719 Caldwell Street.Â  Although 719 Caldwell Street was acquired by both parties from the proceeds of a note and mortgage, of which Husband was an obligor together with Wife, both properties were in Wifeâ€™s name until they were sold on March 11, 2002.Â  After the parties separated, Wife entered into an installment sales contract to sell 719 Caldwell Street to her son for $36,000.Â  The property was previously valued on their 2000 Income Tax Return at $52,135 and was being depreciated as an investment property.Â  Prior to trial, the parties stipulated that 719 Caldwell Street was marital property.Â  Based in part on his role in obtaining the property, Husband asserted the difference in value between the amount Wife sold the property to her son and its value as reflected on their tax returns, should be credited towards the marital estate.
Throughout the marriage, Husband and Wife placed their incomes in a joint account, out of which Wife paid all the expenses associated with the marriage.Â  Wife testified that she voluntarily retired at the end of the 1994 school year as a full time employee of the Newberry County School District at a salary of more than $30,000 per year.Â  From that time forward, she drew regularly from her non-marital IRA account to assist with the partiesâ€™ living expenses.Â  In fact, she withdrew approximately $219,000 from her IRA during her eight-year period of unemployment.Â  
Husband maintained four retirement accounts, which earned approximately $123,000 during the marriage.Â  However, in his answers to interrogatories, Husband listed only his Thrift Savings Plan.Â  Husband testified that he failed to mention the other accounts because the Thrift Savings Plan was the only account to which he voluntarily contributed.Â  Husband denied he intentionally misled the court regarding the retirement accounts, but based his responses upon a misunderstanding.Â  
Both Husband and Wife testified that during the marriage they lived a lifestyle beyond their means.Â  As a result, the parties accumulated a great deal of credit card debt throughout the marriage.Â  The debt as of June 2001 was $33,700.Â  Husband and Wife also spent money to renovate their marital home.Â  Husband testified that he performed many repairs on the home, including replacing numerous support beams.Â  
Around June 2001, the couple mutually inventoried all property in the partiesâ€™ possession.Â  They agreed to conduct an auction to sell the majority of the marital assets as well as some non-marital assets.Â  The auction was held in June 2001 and the sale of marital assets generated $34,500.Â  Wife used the proceeds to pay off marital debt.Â  Much of the contention at trial came from the fact that after the parties separated, Husband moved out of the home and thereafter did not assist Wife in making the mortgage payments.Â  In fact, it was not until he was ordered to do so by the court that Husband contributed $498.00 a month to help with the mortgage payments.Â  Husband made those payments from December 2001 through March 2002. 
The family court concluded the partiesâ€™ marital contributions were nearly equivalent, with Wife contributing more income during the early years of the marriage and Husband contributing more income in the latter stages.Â  The family court ordered each party to be responsible for his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Wife moved for reconsideration of this order.Â  Following a hearing, the family court amended the order to correct clerical mistakes and to account for Husbandâ€™s three previously undisclosed retirement accounts.Â  The family court ordered Wife to pay Husband $1,465.76 to equalize and divide the equity in the marital property and debts.Â  The family court denied relief on all other issues raised in Wifeâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œNor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of her burden to convince this court the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.      Transmutation of 725 and 723 Caldwell Street 
Wife contends the family court erred in finding a portion of the residence at 725 Caldwell Street and the adjoining apartment at 723 Caldwell Street were transmuted.Â  We affirm as modified.
Under the Equitable Apportionment of Marital Property Act, property acquired by either party before the marriage is nonmarital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2005). Â â€œIn certain circumstances, however, nonmarital property . . . may be transmuted into marital property during the marriage.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 295, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988), cert. denied, 298 S.C. 117, 378 S.E.2d 445 (1989).

  Property, nonmarital at the time of its acquisition, may be transmuted (1) if it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) if it is titled jointly; or (3) if it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.Â  

Trimnal v. Trimnal, 287 S.C. 495, 497-98, 339 S.E.2d 869, 870 (1986).Â  Transmutation is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.Â  Johnson at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 110.Â  The spouse claiming transmutation must produce objective evidence showing that, during the marriage, the parties themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.Â Â  Id. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 111.
Husband contends the family court did not base its decision on the theory that the properties had been transmuted, but instead, based its decision on an award of a â€œspecial equity.â€Â  In fact, Husband never sought a finding of transmutation.Â  However, the family court found that with regard to the marital residence a portion of it was transmuted.Â  The family court went on to state â€œ[t]he Plaintiff also during the marriage performed maintenance and repairs on the said property, thereby increasing the value of the property.Â  This [family] Court finds that the husband has 20% equity in 723-725 Caldwell home.â€Â  In explaining its order, the family court stated that its apportionment was based on â€œ[Husbandâ€™s] efforts in working with the house and then the amount thatâ€™s transmuted by the mortgage.â€Â  Additionally, Wife testified, and Husband confirmed, that Wifeâ€™s will, executed early in the marriage, gave Husband a life estate in the marital home should she predecease him.Â  
The evidence produced at trial does not support a finding that the property was transmuted.Â  â€œThe mere use of separate property to support a marriage, without some additional evidence of intent to treat it as property of the marriage, is not sufficient to establish transmutation.â€Â  Id. at 295-96, 372 S.E.2d at 111.Â  In addition, the use of marital funds to make improvements to property, without more, is insufficient to establish intent to transmute property.Â  Stefan v. Stefan, 320 S.C. 419, 424, 465 S.E.2d 734, 737 (Ct. App. 1995).
In Husbandâ€™s direct examination, his attorney inquired â€œ[n]ow, are you asking this court to award you a special â€“ I am going to call it a special equity in the enhanced value of the home?â€Â  To which Husband answered â€œyes.â€Â  At that point Husbandâ€™s counsel said â€œ[a]ll right.Â  Now, your honor, may we approach?Â  I donâ€™t want to make an error.â€Â  Following an off-the-record discussion, Husbandâ€™s counsel made his case for special equity and never mentioned transmutation.Â  During cross examination, Husband stated â€œI still am not asking for part of the house . . . [but am asking for] [m]y sweat equity and also my financial contribution.â€
A spouse has a special equity in any increase in the value of nonmarital property during the marriage to the extent the increase resulted directly or indirectly from efforts of the spouse during marriage.Â  Webber v. Webber, 285 S.C. 425, 427-28, 330 S.E.2d 79, 81 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Husband testified as to repairs he performed for the home including replacing numerous support beams.Â  The equitable interest in the properties awarded to Husband was substantiated by evidence presented at trial, and was therefore proper.Â  Though Husband is not entitled to have the property apportioned as transmuted property, he is entitled to a special equity.Â  
II.      Equitable Apportionment
The apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bungener v. Bungener, 291 S.C. 247, 251, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  On appeal, this court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that the appellate court would have arrived at a different apportionment.Â  Id.Â  
A. Rental Property Expenses
Wife contends the family court erred in failing to take into account expenses she incurred in the upkeep of the rental properties from the time of separation until the hearing.Â  She argues the court erred when it awarded Husband an interest in one-half of the rent received from 719 Caldwell Street and twenty percent of the rent from the garage apartment at 723 Caldwell Street.Â  We disagree.Â  
Wifeâ€™s expenses included maintaining and repairing the property from the time of separation until the hearing, or at least until she sold the property.Â  During this time, Husband did not live in or maintain the house.Â  The trial court deducted from Husbandâ€™s property 50% of the marital debt from 723 and 725 Caldwell Street paid by Wife during the separation.Â  Furthermore, Wife failed to present any evidence of additional maintenance expenses at trial.Â  The trial courtâ€™s apportionment of the property and the debt incurred from the property was not an abuse of discretion.Â  
B.Â  Marital Assets Retained by Husband 
Wife contends the family court erred in failing to take into account the marital assets retained by Husband.Â  We disagree. Â 
At issue are two antique oil lamps and a 1991 Mercedes Benz that Husband obtained to replace the 1982 Mercedes Benz the parties purchased during the marriage.Â  Wife failed to prove, during trial, the value of any lamps.Â  The only mention of antique lamps came when Wife testified as to why there existed so much credit card debt and she replied, â€œ[w]e bought a lot of antiques.Â  We bought at least a dozen antique oil lamps and a dozen antique clocks.â€Â  On the other hand, the two automobiles were mentioned. Â There was testimony that Wife kept one car owned by the couple while Husband kept the Mercedes Benz.Â  
Apportionment of the marital estate is within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 357, 396 S.E.2d 124, 126 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  There was no evidence presented at trial concerning the value of the lamps.Â  There was only a slight difference in the value of the two automobiles, which the family court considered.Â  We find no abuse of discretion and affirm the family courtâ€™s determination on this matter. 
III. Value of 719 Caldwell Street 
Wife contends the family court erred in valuing 719 Caldwell Street at $52,135 where the preponderance of the evidence established the fair market value was $36,000.Â  We disagree.Â  
Husband testified the value of 719 Caldwell Street was $52,135, which was the value the parties listed on their Income Tax Returns in 2000.Â  Wife testified she sold the property to her son for $36,000.
The family court has broad discretion in adopting the value of property. Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating the family courtâ€™s valuation of property will be affirmed if it is within the range of the evidence); Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 198, 363 S.E.2d 404, 407 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding the family court may accept one partyâ€™s valuation of marital property over that of the other party).Â  The family courtâ€™s valuation was within the range of evidence presented at trial.Â  The family court found the sale between Wife and her son was not an armâ€™s length transaction and thus, determined the value based upon the evidence presented at trial.Â  We find no abuse of discretion and affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that the correct value was $52,135. 
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs 
Wife contends the family court erred in denying her request for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We disagree.Â  
In determining whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider the following factors:Â  the partyâ€™s ability to pay his/her own attorneyâ€™s fees; beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M, 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the family court should consider the nature, extent and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
Wife asserts that because Husband failed to present his retirement accounts in their entirety during discovery, she should be awarded attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The court denied this request and stated â€œthere are two things really that ran up the attorneyâ€™s fees here.Â  One is his retirement, as you just mentioned, and the second is the argument over whether or not a portion of the house was transmuted.â€Â  
â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€ Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  We have reviewed the family courtâ€™s failure to award attorneyâ€™s fees in light of the applicable factors and find no abuse of discretion.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.[1]Â  
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Felicia McDaniels and Bernard Holmes, and Child: Mecca Holmes/DOB: 09/08/93 Child: Jeremy Holmes/DOB: 
          09/28/94/ Of Whom Felicia McDaniels is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-129
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 8, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Beaufort, for Appellant.
        Tracy Oâ€™Kelly Klatt, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
        Stacey Patterson Canaday, of Beaufort, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Felicia McDaniels appeals from the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights to her two children.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
McDaniels and Bernard Holmes had two children together, Mecca Holmes, born September 8, 1993 and Jeremy Holmes, born September 28, 1994.Â  McDaniels and Holmes, who were never married, ended their romantic relationship shortly after Jeremyâ€™s birth.Â  The children lived with McDaniels in her home in Los Angeles County, California until 1999 when they came to live with their father in South Carolina.Â  The children were removed from Holmesâ€™ residence by the South Carolina Department of Social Services based on allegations of physical abuse by Holmes of both children and later allegations of sexual abuse of Mecca by Holmes.Â  
The County of Los Angeles Department of Children and Family Services conducted two home studies on McDaniels.Â  In the first study, the social worker recommended the children not be returned to McDaniels at that time.Â  In the second study, however, the social worker did recommend they be returned to her.Â  During the time that the children have been in foster care, McDaniels has not visited them or sent any child support.Â  
After a hearing at which neither parent appeared,[2] the family court ordered termination of the parental rights of McDaniels and Holmes to both children.Â  The court found as grounds to support termination that the children had been in foster care for fifteen of the past twenty-two months, that McDaniels had willfully failed to support the children or make a material contribution to their care, and that she had willfully failed to visit them.Â  In addition, the court held termination of parental rights was in the best interests of the children.Â  The court subsequently denied McDanielsâ€™ motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 â€œIn a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before a parentâ€™s rights may be terminated, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Department of Soc. Servs. v. Mrs. H, 346 S.C. 329, 333, 550 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.Â  However, our broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court or ignore the fact that the family court was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
DISCUSSION
Under South Carolinaâ€™s TPR statute, â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â  The family court found the following grounds to terminate McDanielâ€™s parental rights:Â  1) the children had been in foster care for fifteen out of the past twenty-two months, (2) McDaniels had willfully failed to support the children, and (3) she had willfully failed to visit them.Â  
Our statutory scheme provides a ground for termination of parental rights where the child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005).Â  It is undisputed that the children had been in foster care since April 5, 2002.Â  The order terminating McDanielsâ€™ parental rights was entered May 20, 2004.Â  Accordingly, we find clear and convincing evidence supports this ground for termination.Â  
Section 20-7-1572(4) provides as a ground for termination:

  The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child. Â Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.

Whether a parentâ€™s failure to support a child is willful is a question of intent to be determined from all the facts and circumstances in each case.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 52, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  The trial judge is given wide discretion in making this determination.Â  Id.Â  However, the element of willfulness must be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.Â  â€œParental conduct â€˜which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€˜willfulâ€™ because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€™â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 137, 538 S.E.2d 285, 289 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Broome, 307 S.C. at 53, 413 S.E.2d at 839).
McDaniels is unemployed and has two other children.Â  However, she receives $704 in cash aid a month and $195 for food stamps.Â  She also has Section 8 housing.Â  Her monthly expenses amount to $528.Â  Although her income exceeds her expenses, she failed to pay any support for the children and has only sent them coloring books since they were placed in foster care.Â  We find clear and convincing evidence to support the family courtâ€™s finding that McDaniels willfully failed to support the children.Â Â Â  
Having found at least one ground on which the family court properly terminated McDanielsâ€™ parental rights, we need only determine that termination of McDanielsâ€™ rights is in the best interest of the children.[3]Â  The interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interests and the parental rights conflict.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 259, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999).
Although the social worker that performed the second home study for the Los Angeles Department of Children and Family Services recommended the children be returned to McDaniels, the guardian ad litem took exception to this conclusion and recommended termination of McDanielsâ€™ parental rights.Â  The guardian noted that the children had expressed a desire to go back to their mother.Â  However, their reason for stating this was always, â€œBecause she beats me less than Dad does.â€Â  The guardian testified that McDaniels had called her very regularly in the beginning, but when the guardian refused to put up with her abusive language, McDaniel ceased communicating with her.Â  The Los Angeles social worker noted that McDaniels â€œappears to have a great deal of anger and has at times dealt with this anger in the form of inappropriate letters, phone calls and threats.â€Â  The social worker had concerns about this anger problem but found it did not appear to manifest itself as a risk towards her two young children who live with her.Â  McDaniels has been prescribed Prozac, but she admits she does not take it every day as prescribed.Â  There is no evidence in the record that McDaniels has seen the children since she sent them to live with their father in 1999.
When the children were originally placed in foster care, they were very frightened and withdrawn.Â  At the time of the hearing, they were doing well in their foster home and were back on the honor roll in school.Â  The foster parents have expressed an interest in adopting them.Â  
We find clear and convincing evidence that termination of McDanielsâ€™ parental rights is in the best interest of the children.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]McDanielsâ€™ appointed counsel filed a motion requesting the court order DSS to pay for transportation costs for McDaniels so that she could attend the final hearing.Â  The court denied the request noting counsel failed to provide the court with authority allowing it to order such costs.Â  
[3] As we find clear and convincing evidence to support other grounds, we do not address the ground of willful failure to visit.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

 

  
    
      
        Scott Unger, a New York Individual; Mitchell Realty, Inc., a South Carolina Corporation; and 
          Craftmasters General Contractors, Inc., a South Carolina Corporation, Appellants/Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Theodore Leviton, a New York Individual; Fountainbrook Associates, LLC, a South Carolina 
          Corporation; and Grand South Bank, a South Carolina Banking Institution, Defendants,
        Of Whom Theodore Leviton, a New York Individual and Fountainbrook Associates, LLC, 
          a South Carolina Corporation are the Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-130
Heard February 8, 2006 â€“ Filed March 8, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        J. Stephen Welch, of Greenwood; John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellants/Respondents.
        James E. Bryan, Jr. and Thomas J. Thompson, of Laurens, for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Scott Unger, Mitchell Realty, and Craftmasters General Contractors appeal the grant of summary judgment on various contractual actions against Theodore Leviton and Fountainbrook Associates arising out of a failed business relationship.Â  Leviton and Fountainbrook cross-appeal contempt findings and sanctions issued against them in a related proceeding.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
In 1995, Scott Unger, a New York resident, signed a contract with an entity called HeadSouth to build houses in the Fountainbrook subdivision (the subdivision) in Laurens County, South Carolina.Â  The subdivision property belonged to Eric Hedrick, the sole shareholder of HeadSouth.Â  
Hedrick later experienced financial problems and was unable to continue developing the subdivision.Â  Unger then approached Theodore Leviton, also of New York, to see if Leviton would invest in the project.Â  Together, Unger and Leviton traveled to South Carolina to view the project site. 
Leviton apparently agreed to participate in the project and formed Fountainbrook, Inc., (the Corporation), which was to hold certain properties that were deeded to it.Â  Hedrick, with Levitonâ€™s assistance, formed VAE, Inc.Â  Concurrently with the formation of the Corporation and VAE, Leviton and Hedrick formed Fountainbrook Associates, LLC (the LLC), giving 65 per cent of the ownership of this entity to the Corporation and the remaining 35 per cent to VAE.Â  On or about April 5, 1996, HeadSouth conveyed two parcels of real estate to the Corporation. Both properties either adjoined or were close to the subdivision.
Soon after the formation of the LLC, Unger formed Craftmasters General Contractors, Inc. (Craftmasters), of which he became president and sole shareholder.Â  Craftmasters became the general contractor for the subdivision, supervising the building of the infrastructure.Â  Craftmasters also had the opportunity to bid on infrastructure projects and was awarded a project if it was the lowest bidder.Â  Later, Craftmasters received the exclusive right to construct residences in the subdivision.
In addition, Leviton, Unger, and Hedrick agreed to form Mitchell Realty, Inc., (Mitchell) of which, at the time of this litigation, Unger was the sole shareholder.[1]Â  Sometime during 1996, Mitchell executed an undated written agreement with â€œall home builders selected by [the LLC] to build in their Fountainbrook subdivision.â€Â  The agreement further provided that Mitchell would â€œbe the exclusive on site marketing agent for the subdivision.â€Â  The agreement was signed by Unger in his capacity as president of Mitchell, Leviton in his capacity as managing partner of the LLC; and a representative of a construction company not involved in this litigation.Â  It was to last 36 months and was renewable for additional twelve-month periods.Â  
Unger maintained that, pursuant to an oral agreement he made with Leviton, he was to receive a half interest in the Corporation in exchange for his time, services, and expertise in managing the subdivision.Â  Leviton, however, contended he agreed to share the profits with Unger at an undetermined percentage only after completion of the subdivision and provided Unger had performed properly.
Leviton, his wife, and Gloria Brill were owners of MacLeben Associates, LLC.Â  Around the same time as the subdivision was being developed, MacLeben bought real property to be held by Hewlett Associates, LLC, and Glen Oaks Associates, LLC.Â  Although there is no written documentation that Unger had any ownership interests in Hewlett or Glen Oaks or provided capital for the benefit of these entities, Unger testified he contributed his time and expertise to the development of these properties with the understanding that he would receive an ownership interest in each of the projects. 
Mitchell, Craftmasters, and the LLC used the same office complex until 2000, when Leviton ended his business relationships with Unger and forced Mitchell, Craftmasters, and Unger out of the complex. 
On June 22, 2000, Unger, Mitchell Realty, and Craftmasters (collectively referred to as Plaintiffs) brought suit against Leviton and the LLC (collectively referred to as Defendants) alleging sixteen causes of action arising out of the aborted business relationship and requesting actual and punitive damages as well as injunctive relief.Â  Defendants answered and counterclaimed, and Plaintiffs filed replies.
After the parties completed discovery, Defendants moved for summary judgment.Â  The trial court heard the matter on August 19, 2002.Â  While the summary judgment motion was under advisement, the trial court signed a consent order in which the parties agreed that Defendants would follow certain procedures when selling the subdivision property.Â  The procedures included providing the Plaintiffs with accountings and depositing certain funds into an account held by the Clerk of Court for Laurens County pending final disposition of the case.
On June 12, 2003,[2] the trial court signed an order granting Leviton summary judgment on four causes of action for breach of contract, two actions for tortious interference with contracts, and two claims for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations.[3]Â  The same day, the trial court also issued a contempt order against Defendants, finding they failed to give an accounting to Plaintiffs as required by prior order and ordering Defendants to pay Plaintiffs $2,000 as a sanction for noncompliance.Â  After Defendants unsuccessfully moved for reconsideration, both parties appealed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Plaintiffs contend the trial court erred in finding the purported agreement between the LLC and Mitchell was unenforceable against the LLC.Â  We find no reversible error.
â€œA contract exists where there is an agreement between two or more persons upon sufficient consideration either to do or not to do a particular act.Â  The essentials of a contract include an offer and acceptance.â€[4]Â  
Plaintiffs based this breach of contract claim on two listing agreements signed by Leviton as managing partner for the LLC, by Unger, for Mitchell Realty, and by a third party representing the builders.Â  Both agreements were â€œeffective for a period of thirty-six (36) months from the date of execution of this contractâ€ and were â€œrenewable for additional twelve (12) month periods.â€Â  Neither agreement, however, was dated, and there is no evidence that either agreement was ever renewed.Â  
The trial court found the listing agreements were deficient in several respects to fulfill the requirements of a contractual obligation between Mitchell and the LLC.Â  First, based on its interpretation of the language of the agreements, the court concluded they â€œcontemplated future arrangements between Mitchell and home builders selected by [the LLC].â€Â  Second, the court noted the agreements â€œcontained no provision(s) obligating [the LLC] to Mitchell.â€Â  Third, the court found â€œno listing agreements were in existenceâ€ at the critical time.
We have found nothing in Plaintiffsâ€™ appellantsâ€™ brief challenging the trial courtâ€™s finding that the listing agreements on which they based their contract claim were not â€œin existence.â€[5]Â  Absent such a challenge, we hold this unappealed finding is a sufficient basis to affirm the grant of summary judgment on this cause of action.[6]
2.Â  We agree, however, with Plaintiffsâ€™ contention that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on their action for breach of contract between the LLC and Craftmasters.
The trial court cited the following reasons to support its grant of summary judgment on this claim:Â  â€œPlaintiffs inability to state with any degree of certainty their damages flowing from the alleged breach of contract by [the LLC]; Plaintiffs uncertainty as to which Defendant was a party to the alleged contract; and the alleged Contract is in violation of the Statute of Frauds.â€
As to damages, Plaintiffs presented a letter from Ungerâ€™s accountant to Leviton stating that Craftmasters was owed $196,830.Â  Leviton signed the letter as manager of the LLC, confirming it was in agreement with his records.Â  Without explanation, the trial court stated it was â€œunconvinced that this letter constitutes sufficient proof of damages.â€Â  
We, however, find otherwise.Â  â€œAt the summary judgment stage of the proceedings, the nonmoving party need only submit a scintilla of evidence warranting determination by a jury for summary judgment to be denied.â€[7]Â  Moreover, as the supreme court has noted, â€œ â€˜[t]he law does not require absolute certainty of data upon which lost profits are to be estimated, but all that is required is such reasonable certainty that damages may not be based wholly upon speculation or conjecture.â€™ â€[8]
We also agree with Plaintiffs that the trial court erred in finding the contract was required to be in writing pursuant to the Statute of Frauds.
The statute of frauds requires a contract that is not to be performed within a year of the making to be in writing.[9]Â  Nevertheless, â€œ[t]he fact that performance within a year is highly improbable or not expected by the parties does not bring a contract within the scope of this clause.â€[10]Â  Moreover, â€œa trial court should submit an issue concerning the statute of frauds to the jury if there is evidence on which a finding either way might reasonably be made.â€[11] Â 
 Here, the alleged contract was for Craftmasters to oversee and manage the subdivision.Â  In their pleadings, Plaintiffs alleged Craftmastersâ€™ duties included various general duties related to the development of the subdivision.Â  Although the parties may have contemplated that performance would take longer than a year, it was nevertheless possible that the work could be completed within a year or that the project would be abandoned within that time.Â  Under either of these scenarios, Craftmasters and the LLC could both perform their obligations within a year; therefore, the statute of frauds would not bar enforcement of their agreement.
Finally, we disagree with the trial courtâ€™s determination that Plaintiffs were â€œuncertain as to whether the alleged Contract was between Craftmasters and Leviton or Craftmasters and [the LLC].â€Â  In his deposition, Unger stated the agreement was with the LLC â€œassuming that [Leviton] is representing them.â€Â  Unger also stated Leviton â€œpersonally guaranteed in the beginning of the project that he will cover all expenses.â€Â  Furthermore, Leviton himself acknowledged that he and Unger agreed Craftmasters would act as the general contractor on the entire development and that sometime later he agreed not to look for any other builders.Â  We hold this evidence, when viewed in the light most favorable to Plaintiffs, creates an issue of fact as to whether Craftmasters had an agreement with either Leviton or the LLC or both defendants.
3.Â  Plaintiffs further argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on their cause of action for breach of contract arising from Levitonâ€™s refusal to convey an ownership interest in the Corporation to Unger.Â  We reject this contention.Â  
The trial court determined any alleged agreement between Unger and Leviton for an equity interest in the Corporation was unenforceable as a matter of law because it was not in writingâ€”as required by statute when it was purportedly executedâ€”and because it was barred by the doctrine of judicial estoppel based on an inconsistent statement Unger made during another lawsuit.Â  We affirm the grant of summary judgment on this cause of action, finding no reversible in the trial courtâ€™s application of judicial estoppel.[12]
In Cothran v. Brown, the supreme court adopted the following requirements for the application of judicial estoppel:

  (1) two inconsistent positions taken by the same party or parties in privity with one another; (2) the positions must be taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with each other; (3) the party taking the position must have been successful in maintaining that position and have received some benefit; (4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and (5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent.[13]

The â€œinconsistent positionâ€ on which the trial court based its determination that judicial estoppel barred this claim came from a 1998 deposition Unger gave in a 1997 lawsuit in which the LLC, HeadSouth, Craftmasters, Unger, Hedrick, and Leviton were named as defendants. In the deposition, Unger testified he had no interest in either the LLC or the â€œentity which has an interest inÂ  [the LLC].â€Â  In an affidavit submitted in the present case, Unger maintained he disavowed any ownership interest in either the LLC or the Corporation â€œbased on Mr. Levitons insistence and [his attorneyâ€™s] advise.â€
The trial court found as a matter of law (1) the earlier litigation was related to the present case in that both involved claims by Unger; (2) Unger received a benefit from taking the position he asserted in the prior litigation; (3) Unger â€œadmit[ted] that he intentionally lied during the course of his Deposition relative to the [prior case] and therefore it is clear that Unger clearly intended to mislead the Courtâ€; and (4) Ungerâ€™s position in the prior lawsuit regarding his ownership interest in the Corporation was totally inconsistent with his position in the present matter.
In disputing the trial courtâ€™s finding that the two lawsuits were â€œrelatedâ€ for the purpose of applying judicial estoppel, Plaintiffs argue only the following:

  [T]he alleged inconsistent position was not taken â€œin the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with each other,â€ so the testimony did not give rise to a judicial estoppel.Â  Although both actions may have dealt with issues relative to the Subdivision, the actions did not have the relation contemplated by the doctrine of judicial doctrine estoppel. 

This argument offers nothing by way of explanation of the pertinent facts or supporting authority as to why the trial court was incorrect in finding that the proceedings were related.Â  It is not this courtâ€™s responsibility to ferret out the facts from the record or to find the authority to support an appellantâ€™s contentions.[14]Â  
As to the requirement that the prior proceeding involve â€œthe same party or parties in privity with each other,â€ Unger argues only that the plaintiff in the prior litigation was not connected with any of the parties in the present lawsuit.Â  There is no requirement, however, that the prior litigation be restricted to those parties in the present case.Â  Rather, privity is required only between the party against whom the doctrine of judicial estoppel is asserted and the party who made the inconsistent statement in the prior proceeding.[15]
Plaintiffs further argue that â€œUnger has received no benefitâ€ because both he and Leviton were defendants in the earlier case.Â  This argument, however, does not discredit the trial courtâ€™s findings that Unger was successful in the prior lawsuit in that the case was dismissed and no judgment was taken against either Unger or Craftmasters.[16]
Finally, Plaintiffs contend Leviton should not be allowed to assert the doctrine of judicial estoppel because of his own misconduct in instructing Unger to give an untruthful answer during the deposition.Â  The trial court did not address this argument, and the record does not indicate Plaintiffs moved for a post-trial ruling on the matter; therefore, we hold Plaintiffs have not preserved this argument for appeal.[17]
4.Â  Plaintiffs further contend the trial court erred in summarily dismissing their claim for breach of contract arising out of an alleged oral agreement by Leviton to convey Unger ownership interests in Hewlett Associates and Glen Oaks.Â  We hold summary judgment on this cause of action was premature.
The trial court found that, when the parties allegedly made the agreement, it was not enforceable under then-existing South Carolina Code section 36-8-319 because it was not in writing.[18]Â  
We do not necessarily accept Plaintiffsâ€™ contention that, because the present version of section 36-8-103 classifies a limited liability company as a security under only very limited circumstances, the transaction at issue was not subject to section 36-8-319.[19]Â  Nevertheless, Plaintiffs correctly argue the entities at issue here are both limited liability companies, which, under the law in effect at the time of the agreement would be â€œsecuritiesâ€ subject to section 36-8-319 only if accompanied by other criteria, none of which were shown to be applicable here.[20]Â  We therefore reverse the grant of summary judgment on this cause of action and remand the claim for a determination of whether Unger and Leviton had an agreement regarding the transfer of interests in the Hewlett and Glen Oaks properties.
5.Â  We reject Plaintiffsâ€™ arguments concerning summary judgment on their causes of action for tortious interference with Craftmastersâ€™ contract with Grand South Bank, which financed the project, and Mitchellâ€™s contracts with various builders and realtors.Â  
 â€œThe elements of a cause of action for tortious interference with contract are:Â  (1) existence of a valid contract; (2) the wrongdoerâ€™s knowledge thereof; (3) his intentional procurement of its breach; (4) the absence of justification; and (5) resulting damages.â€[21]
As to Craftmastersâ€™ contract with Grand South, the trial court found (1) Plaintiffs did not identify any particular contractual arrangements between themselves and the bank; and (2) Plaintiffs failed to provide evidence of any actions or inactions by Defendants that could have amounted to interference with any such arrangements.Â  
Assuming without deciding that Craftmasters had an existing arrangement for financing with Grand South, we agree with the trial court that Plaintiffs failed to provide evidence of any acts or misconduct by Defendants that could rise to the level of tortious interference with this contract.Â  In their appellantsâ€™ brief, Plaintiffs assert Defendants encouraged Craftmasters to use the loan proceeds obtained from the bank â€œfor the general development of [the LLC], based upon . . . [D]efendantsâ€™ promise to quickly repay the funds so that they could be used on the original lots identified under the contracts with the Bank.â€Â  They further maintain Defendants then â€œrefused to repay the funds as agreed, and then encouraged the Bank to pursue breach of contract claims in the hope of damaging Plaintiffs and forcing Craftmasters and Unger out of the project.â€
Here, however, the party purportedly in breach was Craftmasters, not Grand South Bank.Â  These accusations, then, even if true, do not entitle Plaintiffs to sue for tortious interference with contract.[22]Â  
As to contracts Mitchell may have had with various builders and realtors, we find no reason to reverse the trial courtâ€™s finding that Plaintiffs failed to provide evidence that any such agreements existed.Â  In their appellantsâ€™ brief, Plaintiffs argue only that they alleged in their complaint that Leviton and the LLC â€œwere aware of certain contractual relationships between [Mitchell] and other builders and realtors in the area related to the Fountainbrook Developmentâ€; however, they never cited any evidence supporting this allegation or identified any of the other parties to the purported contracts.[23]
6.Â  Plaintiffs further contend the trial court should not have granted summary judgment on their cause of action for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations between Mitchell and various third parties.Â  We find no error.Â  
â€œTo recover on a cause of action for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations, . . . the plaintiff must prove: (1) the defendant intentionally interfered with the plaintiffâ€™s potential contractual relations; (2) for an improper purpose or by improper methods; (3) causing injury to the plaintiff.â€[24]Â  â€œThe plaintiff must actually demonstrate, at the outset, that he had a truly prospective (or potential) contract with a third party.â€[25]Â  â€œ[P]laintiffs must allege â€˜either a business relation with specific third parties or with an identifiable prospective class of third persons.â€™ â€[26] 
In support of its grant to summary judgment on this cause of action, the trial court found Plaintiffs failed to present sufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case.Â  In addition, the trial court found their request for damages was â€œhighly speculative at best, and thus barred by the holding in Hendricks vs. Clemson University.â€[27]
Plaintiffsâ€™ argument in their appellantsâ€™ brief focuses on their allegation that Defendants denied them access to information and materials that Mitchell needed to show subdivision property to prospective buyers.[28]Â  Because, however, Plaintiffs did not challenge the finding that their damages were speculative, we find no reason to reverse the grant of summary judgment.[29]
7.Â  We also affirm the grant of summary judgment on Plaintiffsâ€™ cause of action for intentional interference with prospective contracts that Craftmasters had relative to construction in the subdivision.Â  The trial court found Plaintiffs were unable to identify any potential contracts or parties with whom prospective contracts were pending.Â  On appeal, Plaintiffs do not point to any evidence in the record that would indicate Craftmasters had any pending sales agreements that would support a cause of action for interference with prospective contractual relations.[30]
8.Â  Defendants argue the trial court erred in holding Leviton in contempt.Â  We disagree.
â€œA determination of contempt is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, but is subject to reversal where based on a finding that is without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€[31]Â  â€œWilful disobedience of a court order will justify a finding of contempt.â€[32]Â  
The trial court found Leviton in contempt because he failed to comply with the provision in the consent order requiring him to provide Unger with accountings of sales proceeds and to follow certain other procedures required of him.Â  These findings were supported by Ungerâ€™s testimony that, although he received basic information that potential sales of property in the subdivision were pending, he never received preliminary cost estimates or a full accounting as required by the consent order.Â  Furthermore, contrary to the terms of the consent order, no money had ever been paid to the Clerk of Court from any of the sales proceeds.Â  We therefore hold the finding of contempt was supported by the evidence and within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.
9.Â  We agree, however, with Defendants that the trial court erred in imposing a $2,000 sanction on Leviton.
â€œWhere compensation [for civil contempt] is extended, a fine is imposed, payable to the complainant. Such fine must of course be based upon evidence of complainant's actual loss.â€[33]Â  â€œIncluded in the actual loss are the costs in defending and enforcing the courtâ€™s order, including litigation costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The burden of showing what amount, if anything, the complainant is entitled to recover by way of compensation should be on the complainant.[34]
In the present case, the trial court did not specify whether the contempt was civil or criminal.Â  The fine, however, was payable to Unger; therefore, the sanction was compensatory and accordingly should have been limited to Ungerâ€™s actual losses.Â  Because trial court did not make findings of Ungerâ€™s actual losses, we remand this issue to the trial court to make the necessary findings of fact and to impose a monetary sanction based on Ungerâ€™s actual losses. Â

[1]Â  Although Unger, Leviton, and Hedrick initially agreed that they would each own one third of Mitchellâ€™s outstanding capital stock, Leviton did not become a stockholder because he lacked a South Carolina real estate brokerâ€™s license.

[4]Â  Benya v. Gamble, 282 S.C. 624, 628, 321 S.E.2d 57, 60 (Ct. App. 1984) (citations omitted).

Preferred Mut. Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 161, 177 S.E.2d 544, 544 (1970) (stating an unchallenged ruling, â€œright or wrong, is the law of [the] case and requires affirmanceâ€).

McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting that, when an appellant fails to cite any supporting authority or when the argument is merely a conclusory statement, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal); Smith v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996) (â€œThe appellant has the burden of providing this court with a sufficient record upon which to make a decision.â€).

Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule on a question and the appellant fails to move under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals and should not be addressed).

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-8-319 (1976); see also Davenport v. Island Ford, Lincoln, Mercury, Inc., 320 S.C. 424, 428-29, 465 S.E.2d 737, 740 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting an oral stock purchase agreement would violate section 36-8-319).Â  The legislature repealed section 36-8-319 in 1999. 1999 S.C. Acts 42 Â§ 4.Â  
[19] As Defendants point out in their respondentsâ€™ brief, the version cited by Plaintiffs is how the statute presently reads, not how it read in 1998, when the transactions allegedly took place.

  The coverage of Article 8â€™s definition of â€œsecurityâ€ is not confined to corporate securities, but would include interests in limited partnerships, oil and gas fractional interests, state and municipal bonds, and the like, provided these investment media meet the further requirements of the definition of â€œsecurity,â€ viz. App. 1992) (â€œThe elements of tortious interference with contract are:Â  1) existence of a contract between plaintiff and a third party; 2) defendantâ€™s knowledge of that contract; 3) defendantâ€™s intentional interference with that contract; 4) breach of that contract by the third party; 5) resulting damages to the plaintiff.â€) (emphasis added); Beck v. App. 2002) (noting as a element of tortious interference with contract that â€œthe defendant intentionally induces the third person not to perform the contractâ€); Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 766 (1979) (â€œ[O]ne who intentionally and improperly interferes with the performance of a contract . . . between another and a third person by inducing or otherwise causing the third person not to perform the contract, is subject to liability to the other . . . [34] Id.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Phyllis Arlene Trammell, Appellant,
				v.
				Bradshaw Automotive Group, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-131
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 8, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James J. Raman, of Spartanburg, for Appellant. 
				
				Bradford Neal Martin, and Laura Wilcox Howle Teer, of Greenville, for Respondent.
				
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: This dispute arises from a car sale that failed due to poor credit.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment for Respondent Bradshaw Automotive Group, Inc.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2).[1]
1.  Appellant informed the salesman at Respondent Bradshaw Automotive that she had poor credit.Â  Appellant, however, omitted important information from the credit application.Â  She signed a handwritten buyerâ€™s order which specified the car to be purchased and contained an itemized price listing.Â  The buyerâ€™s order contained the following language:Â  â€œShould financing be requested, it is understood that no contractual relationship is established and the transaction will not be consummated until credit has been approved . . . .â€Â  Appellant admitted that when she signed the buyerâ€™s order she understood no contract would be established until financing was obtained.Â  Appellant next met with Respondentâ€™s finance manager and signed a typed buyerâ€™s order that contained the same conditional language.Â  Appellant also signed a â€œRetail Installment Contract and Security Agreement,â€ which recited the terms of the proposed sale and provided the details of the financing.Â  The financing contract further provided that it was to be assigned to CPS, Inc.Â  This form was not signed by representatives of either Respondent or CPS.Â  For the next two months, Respondent unsuccessfully attempted to secure financing.Â  CPS denied Appellantâ€™s application for credit.Â  No other lenders approved the application.Â  Respondent ultimately attempted to repossess the car but Appellant locked it in her backyard and brought this action against Respondent.Â 
 
2.  We find the learned circuit court judge properly granted Respondent summary judgment and dismissed the Complaint.Â 
 
Issue I. The contract claim:Â  See Brewer v. Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc., 364 S.C. 444, 449-51, 613 S.E.2d 802, 805-06 (Ct. App. 2005) (detailing a similar transaction and holding that when approval of financing is a condition precedent to the formation of the contract for sale, no duties of performance arise under the contract until financing is approved).Â Â Â  
 
Issue II. The Truth In Lending claim:Â  The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) is a federal statute enacted to protect consumers in credit transactions.Â  Comer v. Person Auto Sales, Inc., 368 F. Supp. 2d 478, 484 (M.D.N.C. 2005).Â  Toward that end, TILA requires creditors to make accurate disclosures when extending credit such as: amount financed, itemization of amount financed, total number of payments, finance charges, annual percentage rate, and identity of the creditor.Â  See 15 U.S.C. Â§ 1638(a) (2005); Bragg v. Bill Heard Chevrolet, Inc., 374 F.3d 1060, 1065, (11th Cir. 2004); Comer, 368 F. Supp. 2d at 484.Â  Also, a customer must be informed of the right to rescind.Â  Oâ€™Brien v. Aames Funding Corp., 374 F. Supp. 2d 764, 766 (D. Minn. 2005).Â  The specific content and timing of the disclosures are set forth in Regulation Z, a Federal Reserve Board regulation.Â  Bragg, 374 F.3d at 1065.Â  Under Regulation Z, the disclosures must be made â€œbefore consummation of the transaction,â€ or â€œbefore credit is extended.â€Â  Nigh v. Koons Buick Pontiac GMC, Inc., 319 F.3d 119, 123 (4th Cir. 2003), revâ€™d on other grounds, 543 U.S. 50 (2004).Â  In Nigh, the Fourth Circuit joined many other courts in holding that consummation, for purposes of TILA, occurs when a customer signs a financing agreement that provides unilateral power for the creditor to execute the agreement at a later time.Â  Id. at 124.Â  Appellant argues that Respondent violated TILA by failing to provide her a copy of the finance agreement before it was executed by the dealership.Â  She cites no law in support of this theory.Â  Conclusory arguments without supporting authority are considered abandoned.Â  Armstrong v. Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 222 n.3, 621 S.E.2d 368, 377 n.3 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In any event, federal case law suggests that a dealership is not required to provide a customer with a separate copy of the disclosures to keep after signing the financing form, so long as the customer is able to review the information before signing it and is provided a copy to take with them after financing is approved.Â  Padin v. Oyster Point Dodge, 397 F.Supp.2d 712, 722 (E.D. Va. 2005) (construing 12 CFR Â§ 226.17(a)(1), which provides that the creditor must make the disclosures â€œclearly and conspicuously in writing, in a form that the consumer may keepâ€); Haun v. Don Mealy Imports, Inc., 285 F. Supp. 2d 1297, 1305-06 (M.D. Fla. 2003) (same).Â  Appellant admitted that she was provided a copy of the conditional agreement; the conditional agreement contained the truth in lending disclosures.Â  
 
Issue III. The Parol Evidence Rule:Â  This issue is not properly preserved for review.Â  See Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-780 (2004) (â€œIssues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when they are raised to and ruled on by the lower court.â€).Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 
 

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Michael D. Simmons, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-132
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 8, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Mr. Michael D. Simmons, of Pelzer, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Simmons appeals convictions for burglary in the first degree and three counts of attempted armed robbery.Â  Specifically, he argues the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department lacked probable cause to arrest him, and that he should have been provided a preliminary hearing prior to trial.Â  We affirm. 
 
FACTS
In the early morning hours of April 30, 2003, Simmons and two other masked men broke into Tarra Hendersonâ€™s home with the intent to steal drugs and money they believed to be in the house.Â  All three men were armed with handguns. [r.31] Tarra Henderson, and her boyfriend, Torrey Brown, were in a room in the front of the residence with their one month-old child, and Donnell Hagood, a mutual friend was asleep in a back bedroom.
 
When Simmons and his co-defendants entered the home, one man ordered Brown to the ground and held him at gunpoint while the other man and Simmons searched the house for drugs and money.Â  Simmons opened the oven, turned it on, and threatened to put Hendersonâ€™s baby in the oven if she did not cooperate. 
 
At this point, Henderson yelled for Hagoodâ€™s assistance.Â  When the masked men became aware of Hagoodâ€™s presence, Simmons and the third man went into his room, frisked him, and forced him into the front room at gunpoint.
 
When the first man saw Hagood, he recognized him as his cousin, took off his mask, and stopped holding Brown at gunpoint.Â  When Simmons and the other man saw this, they fled the residence.Â  Henderson called the police who ultimately arrested the intruder.Â 
 
Later, Jeremey Nash turned himself in to police and confessed to being one of the intruders who broke into Tarra Hendersonâ€™s home.Â  During Simmonsâ€™ trial, Nash testified and served as the key witness placing Simmons at the scene as one of the intruders.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Simmons raises two issues in his pro se brief, both of which relate to probable cause.Â  One concern is whether the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department had probable cause to arrest him, and the other asserts that he should have been granted a preliminary hearing.Â  
 
First, there is no question that probable cause existed when the grand jury indicted Simmons.Â  A true billed indictment is prima facie evidence of probable cause.Â  Whitner v. Duke Power Company, 277 S.C. 397, 399, 288 S.E.2d 389, 390 (1982). Furthermore, probable cause for an arrest exists when the circumstances within the arresting officerâ€™s knowledge are sufficient to lead a reasonable person to believe that a crime has been committed by the person being arrested.Â  State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 509, 476 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1996).Â  â€œWhether probable cause exists depends upon the totality of the circumstances surrounding the information at the officerâ€™s disposal.â€Â  Id.Â  After a review of the record, we find the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department possessed probable cause to arrest Simmons.
Second, a defendant does not have a constitutional right to a preliminary hearing in South Carolina.Â  State v. Keenan, 278 S.C. 361, 296 S.E.2d 676 (1982).Â  Simmonsâ€™ indictments constituted a finding of probable cause and thus eliminated the need for a preliminary hearing.Â  State v. McClure, 277 S.C. 432, 289 S.E.2d 158 (1982).Â  Significantly, Simmonsâ€™ attorney declined to request a hearing because he felt it was clear the state had probable cause.Â  We find no error on appeal.
Based on this failure to request a preliminary hearing, Simmons sought his attorneyâ€™s dismissal.Â  The trial judge properly denied this request and continued with the trial.Â  Simmons also argued throughout his brief that his trial counsel was ineffective for refusing to request a preliminary hearing.Â  However, post-conviction relief, rather than direct appeal, is the proper avenue for allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  State v. Felder, 290 S.C. 521, 351 S.E.2d 852 (1986).Â  
 
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
