title: John Doe 3 v. DuCharme
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John Doe 3, Appellant,
v.
William D. DuCharme, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-133
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston, for Appellant.
David B. Betts and Jonathan Matthew Harvey, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The trial court granted DuCharmeâ€™s motion for summary judgment and dismissed Doeâ€™s action for childhood sexual abuse with prejudice.Â  On appeal, Doe argues the trial court erred in deciding his action was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Doe alleged DuCharme sexually abused him in 1986 and 1987 when he was twelve and thirteen years of age, respectively.Â  Doe admitted he did not repress the memory of the abuse, but he claimed that a causal connection between the alleged abuse and his alleged injury was not diagnosed until 2003.Â Â  
DuCharme denied these allegations and moved for summary judgment claiming the statute of limitations for the cause of action had run.Â  On July 9, 2004, the trial court held a hearing to decide DuCharmeâ€™s summary judgment motion.Â  The trial court granted DuCharmeâ€™s summary judgment motion holding that Doeâ€™s cause of action arose in 1987 when he was thirteen years-old, and this cause of action became time barred when he reached his nineteenth birthday.Â  Doeâ€™s cause of action was dismissed with prejudice.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a motion for summary judgment, the appellate court applies
the same standard of review as the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E.2d 437, 443 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Trousdell v. Cannon, 351 S.C. 636, 572 S.E.2d 264 (2002)).Â  The judgment may be affirmed only if there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56, SCRCP.Â Â Â  The reviewing court must consider the facts and inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Estate of Cantrell by Cantrell v. Green, 302 S.C. 557, 559, 397 S.E.2d 777, 779 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing Stratos v. King, 282 S.C. 501, 319 S.E.2d 356 (Ct. App. 1984)). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Doe contends the trial court erred in finding his cause of action to be time barred under the statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
Doe brought suit alleging intentional infliction of emotional distress and battery under section 15-3-555 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  This statute went into effect on August 31, 2001, andÂ  provides a sexual abuse victim with three years from the date of discovery of the causal relationship between the injury and the sexual abuse to file a cause of action.Â  
However, DuCharme moved for summary judgment based on sections 15-3-530(5) and 15-3-40 of the South Carolina Code (1976).Â  These sections of law represented the statutes of limitation governing sexual abuse causes of action prior to August 31, 2001.Â  Section 15-3-530(5) (1976) allowed a sexual abuse victim to file within six years from the date the victim knew or should have known that he had a cause of action.[2]Â  Section 15-3-40 raised exceptions to the six year statute of limitations requirement.[3]Â  More specifically, section 15-3-40 (Supp. 2005)Â  states:

If a person entitled to bring an action mentioned in Article 5 of this chapter or an action under Chapter 78 of this title, except for a penalty or forfeiture or against a sheriff or other officer for an escape, is at the time the cause of action accrued either:
(1) within the age of eighteen years; or
(2) insane;

  the time of the disability is not a part of the time limited for the commencement of the action, except that the period within which the action must be brought cannot be extended:
(a) more than five years by any such disability, except infancy; nor
(b) in any case longer than one year after the disability ceases.

DuCharme argued that while the statute of limitations was tolled during Doeâ€™s minority, his causes of action needed to be commenced within one year of his eighteenth birthday (not later than some time in 1993).Â  DuCharme further contended because the applicable statutes of limitation already had run sometime in 1993 prior to the August 31, 2001 effective date of the more liberal statute of limitations, Doeâ€™s cause of action was time barred.Â  
The trial court agreed with DuCharmeâ€™s argument and concluded:

While it is certainly the authority of the legislature to establish appropriate statutes of limitations for various causes of action, it is without authority to revive a cause of action which has already become time barred at the time such new statute of limitation is enacted.

The trial court went on to state for the purposes of this matter, whether the applicable statute is deemed one of repose or limitation makes no difference.Â  
During the pendency of this appeal, the South Carolina Supreme Court decided a case which had facts virtually identical to this matter.Â  InÂ  Doe v. Crooks, 364 S.C. 349, 613 S.E.2d 536 (2005), a thirty-four year old man was allegedly sexually abused in 1983 as a fourteen or fifteen year old child, and he admitted that his recollection of these events was not repressed.Â  He asserted that he did not realize the full extent of his injuries until 2001.
The supreme court analyzed the issue in the following manner:

Discovery occurred in 1983, when Doe was fifteen years old.Â  Under section 15-3-40(1), the limitations period was tolled until Doe reached the age of majority, eighteen. Under section 15-3-535, Doe then had six years to file his action.Â 
In other words, Doe needed to file by the time he turned twenty-four. Because he failed to do so, his cause of action lapsed in 1992, nine years before section 15-3-555
was adopted. 

Crooks, 364 S.C. at 352-53, 613 S.E.2d at 538.
The supreme court found similarly to the trial court in holding:Â  

Ordinarily, a new statute of limitations applies retroactively.Â  However, it cannot operate to revive an action for which the limitations period has already expired. Such a result would violate the defendantâ€™s rights under the Due Process Clause of the South Carolina Constitution.       

Crooks, 364 S.C. at 351-52, 613 S.E.2d at 538.
Under the supreme courtâ€™s analysis in Crooks, Doe would have had to file his cause of action by sometime in 1998 in order to comply with the then existing statute of limitation.Â  Doe did not file this action until 2003.Â  Therefore, under both the analysis of the trial court and the supreme courtâ€™s analysis in Crooks, Doeâ€™s action is time barred.Â  
We find the supreme courtâ€™s decision in Crooks to be controlling and dispositive of this matter.Â  Therefore, in accordance with this binding precedent, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s granting of summary judgment. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  For actions accruing prior to April 5, 1988, the limitations period is six years in duration. The three-year limitations period now found in the Code applies to actions accruing on or after April 5, 1988.Â  Doe v. Crooks, 364 S.C. 349, 353 n.7, 613 S.E.2d 536, 538 n.7 (2005) (citing 1988 Act No. 432).Â  This action accrued in 1986; however, inserting the proper six year statute of limitation over the improper three year statute of limitation (as put forth by DuCharme) is inconsequential because the trial court set the date of expiration for the cause of action as one year from the victimâ€™s eighteenth birthday.Â  Under either statute of limitation, the cause of action expires in 1993 under the trial courtâ€™s analysis.Â  
[3] There may be exceptions to these statutes of limitation for â€œrepressed memoriesâ€ of sexual abuse, but Doe admits that he did not repress his memory of the abuse.Â  â€œThat the injured party may not at that time â€˜comprehend the full extent of the damage is immaterial.â€™â€Â  Doe v. text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Patricia A. Hocker, Respondent,
v.
Michael B. Hocker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
A. E. Morehead, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-136
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Candice A. Lively, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Melissa Meyers Frazier, of North Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Hocker (Husband) appeals from the family court judgeâ€™s award of alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees, investigative fees and costs to Patricia Hocker (Wife).Â  We affirm.[1]

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife began dating in 1986, when Husband was in his first year of college, and began living together in the fall of 1989.Â  During this time, Wife attended one semester of a community college, worked for a temporary agency, and worked for a mail company.Â  The parties were married in December 1991 while husband was in his third year of medical school and Wife worked as a nanny.Â  Thereafter, the parties moved from Colorado to California for a year for Husbandâ€™s internship.Â  During this time, Wife, who again worked as a nanny, became pregnant with their first child. Their son Michael was born May 1, 1994, and the parties agreed Wife would be a stay-at-home
mother.

Two months after Michaelâ€™s birth, the parties moved from California to Florida, where Husband attended Flight Surgeon School for his military obligation.Â  Six months later, the parties again moved, this time to Hawaii, where they remained for almost three years while Husband was a Flight Surgeon.Â  During this time, Wife continued to stay at home with Michael.Â    
 In May 1997, the parties moved to Massachusetts for Husbandâ€™s three-year residency as an Emergency Room Resident.Â  The first year, Wife continued to stay at home, taking care of Michael.Â  However, she later took a part-time position, at the hospital where Husband worked, performing secretarial work while Michael attended pre-school.Â  During the third year of Husbandâ€™s residency, Wife was pregnant again and stayed home.Â    
 The partiesâ€™ second child, Zachary, was born June 17, 2000.Â  One week later, the parties moved to Myrtle Beach, where Husband took a position as an Emergency Room Physician at Grand Strand Hospital.Â  In the summer of 2001, Melissa Schroeder, who apparently worked with Husband, began babysitting the partiesâ€™ children.Â  The following October, Husband informed Wife he no longer loved her.Â  That Thanksgiving, Wife took the children on an extended holiday visit to Colorado, and after noticing questionable activity on the partiesâ€™ checking account, returned home early to discover evidence of Husbandâ€™s possible infidelity.Â  Once confronted, Husband admitted there was â€œsomebody else in his life,â€ but denied Wife knew the person.Â  On December 1, 2001, Husband moved out of the marital home.Â  Thereafter, Wife hired a private investigator and discovered the woman Husband was having an affair with was the babysitter, Melissa Schroeder.Â  In May, 2002, Melissa Schroeder was accepted into Physicianâ€™s Assistant School at Wake Forest in North Carolina.Â  In June 2002, Husband accepted a position at Duke University in North Carolina, only eighty miles from Melissaâ€™s school.Â  
 After Husband moved to North Carolina, Wife took trips there so Husband could see the children and because she believed they could put their â€œmarriage back together.â€Â  While the parties did discuss Wife moving to North Carolina to be with Husband, they never had a set plan.Â  In September 2002, Wife discovered she was pregnant.Â  She continued to visit Husband in North Carolina during her pregnancy, but found evidence Husband and Melissa were still involved in a relationship.Â  After the birth of their daughter Kylie in April 2003, the parties no longer discussed reconciliation.Â  In June 2004, Wife again hired a private investigator, who discovered evidence that Melissa spent the night in Husbandâ€™s home with the partiesâ€™ children.Â 
Wife filed this action seeking, among other things, a divorce from Husband on the ground of adultery, custody of the children, child support, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband answered, admitting he committed adultery, but alleging Wife condoned his affair based upon their reconciliation.Â  The family court granted Wife a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery, finding the adultery was ongoing and there was no attempt at reconciliation after the last private investigative report.Â  It further awarded Wife custody of the minor children.Â  After considering all the relevant factors, the family court determined Wife was entitled to $5,000 per month in alimony, child support in the amount of $3,000 per month, and attorneyâ€™s fees, expert fees, investigative fees and costs in the amount of $12,000.Â  
Husband appeals, arguing the family court judge erred in awarding Wife $5,000 a month in alimony.Â  He further asserts error in the award of $12,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and investigative fees.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  Rather, because the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony Award
Husband argues that, in determining the amount of alimony to award Wife, the family court committed reversible error because the award was (1) an excessive amount that was not supported by the evidence presented and (2) the amount awarded acted as a disincentive for Wife to seek employment.Â  We disagree.
 A.Â Â Â Â Â  Excessiveness of Award
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding wife $5,000 a month in alimony because the evidence presented did not support this amount.Â  He contends, after involuntary deductions and child support and alimony payments, he is left with only $4,414 a month to cover his own expenses.Â  He further argues Wifeâ€™s financial declaration included only estimations of her monthly expenses and that these estimations were not reasonable.Â  Husband also takes issue with certain specific expenses listed by Wife on her financial declaration, including child care expenses and a loan repayment to Wifeâ€™s parents that was to be discharged in a bankruptcy proceeding the parties had pending.Â  Finally, Husband argues the family court erroneously found the parties enjoyed a high standard of living because the evidence shows the parties lived beyond their means.
The record shows Husband was receiving a gross monthly income of approximately $20,000.Â  Wife, on the other hand, has no source of income other than alimony and child support.Â  After considering the appropriate factors pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C), the family court determined Wife was entitled to monthly alimony of $5,000, approximately one-fourth of Husbandâ€™s gross income.Â  In particular, the family court noted Wifeâ€™s educational background and lack of marketable job skills, Husbandâ€™s employment as a physician and his high monthly gross income of approximately $20,000, the partiesâ€™ previous high standard of living, Husbandâ€™s fault in the break-up of the marriage which significantly impacted the economic circumstances, Husbandâ€™s move to North Carolina which forced the parties to file for bankruptcy, and the beneficial tax consequence of alimony to Husband.Â  The family court further found Wifeâ€™s financial declaration reflected â€œfair and appropriate, actual as well as estimated monthly expenses for herself and the childrenâ€ of some $8,215 per month.Â  
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 292, 617 S.E.2d 359, 362 (2005).Â  The purpose of an alimony award is to serve as a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship, thereby placing the supported spouse, as nearly as practical, in the same position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe family court has broad discretion in determining the amount of permanent alimony, and there is no single, fixed standard to use in making that determination.â€Â  Rimer v. Rimer, 361 S.C. 521, 525, 605 S.E.2d 572, 574 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIt is the duty of the court to make an award of alimony that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim is well-founded.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 504, 478 S.E.2d 854, 860 (Ct. App. 1996).
Factors to be considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations; as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005).Â  No one factor is dispositive.Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001). 
In this case, the family court carefully considered and made written findings on all thirteen factors enumerated in section 20-3-130(C).Â  Based on the record before us, we find this award is supported by the evidence and therefore the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife $5,000 a month in alimony.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
B.   Â Â Â Â  Alimony as a Disincentive
Husband next argues the family court erred in awarding $5,000 a month in alimony as it acts as a disincentive for Wife to seek employment or a better education.Â  We disagree.
The family court found, and the record supports, Wife has a limited education and a sporadic work history that has left her with no marketable job skills.Â  Further, the family court found, as testified to by Wife, if Wife were to obtain employment, her earnings would not cover the costs she would incur in child care.Â  The family court also determined the parties made a joint decision that Wife would primarily be a homemaker.Â  This finding is supported by the testimony of Wife that, once she was expecting their first child, the parties agreed it was in the best interest of the children that Wife stay home with them.Â  Further, Husband himself testified the parties agreed it would be best for the children for Wife to stay home with the children â€œwhile [they] were in school.â€Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in its award of alimony.

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding Wife a full reimbursement of $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $2,000 in investigative fees.Â  We disagree.
In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider the following factors:Â  (1) the partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case, (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case, (3) counselâ€™s professional standing, (4) the contingency of compensation, (5) the beneficial results obtained, and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
Husband contends, while the family court made findings pursuant to the Glasscock factors, it failed to consider all of the factors as raised by the evidence.Â  Specifically, Husband asserts error in the family courtâ€™s failure to recognize that, after his support payment of $8,000 a month, he will not be in a position to pay Wifeâ€™s fees, and his own standard of living will be detrimentally affected by the award.Â  
The family court expressly considered the above factors in making the award of fees and costs.Â  In particular, the court noted Husbandâ€™s misconduct was the cause of the break-up of the marriage, Wifeâ€™s standard of living would be impacted and it would create a financial hardship on her if she were required to pay the fees, Husband earns a substantial income, placing him in a better position to pay the fees, and Wife obtained beneficial results.Â  The court also found Wifeâ€™s attorney to be in good professional standing, the fees charged were comparable to those charged in the community, and the amount of time devoted to the case was reasonable based upon the nature and difficulty of the matter.Â  Under the facts and circumstances of this case, particularly Husbandâ€™s superior earning capacity, his fault in the break-up of the marriage and the resulting impact on Wifeâ€™s financial condition, and the beneficial results obtained by Wifeâ€™s attorney, we find no abuse of discretion in the award.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:

Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 13, 2006

Ronnie Alan Sabb, of Kingstree; for Appellant.
Chalmers C. Johnson and Bonnie T. Hunt, of Charleston; for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Wateree Community Actions, Inc. (also referred to as the Agency) appeals a judgment in a retaliatory discharge action, arguing the plaintiff, Coralen Montgomery, failed to effect service of process.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 4, 2001, Montgomery was fired from her employment as a bus driver and custodian with Wateree Head Start, a division of Wateree Community Actions, Inc., after leaving a child unattended on her bus at the end of her route.Â  In the letter of termination sent to Montgomery, Georgia M. Mance, the Head Start director, cited as the reason for Montgomeryâ€™s discharge her failure to follow certain program policies established to prevent such hazards.
Montgomery appealed her termination in accordance with the Agencyâ€™s internal grievance procedures.Â  Although the Agency acknowledged receipt of her appeal and scheduled a hearing with the Head Start Policy Council Grievance Committee, the hearing was postponed twice at the request of Montgomeryâ€™s attorney.Â  On January 31, 2002, after the second postponement, Mance wrote to Montgomery advising that, because the Head Start Office had not heard from her since her attorney made the second request for a continuance, her appeal had â€œbecome void for lack of timely communication and not following through on an appeal which [she] requested.â€Â  Mance further informed Montgomery the Head Start Policy Council â€œcontinue[d] to uphold its actionâ€ and any further pursuit of her appeal should be done in writing and sent to Rubye J. Johnson, the Agencyâ€™s executive director, at a post office box address in Sumter.Â  Apparently, however, Montgomery did not continue her appeal within the Agency.
On May 22, 2002, Montgomery filed a summons and complaint against the Agency for wrongful discharge.Â  In her pleadings, Montgomery alleged the Agency had fired her in retaliation for a workersâ€™ compensation claim she had filed.Â  Montgomeryâ€™s attorney served the pleadings by certified mail, return receipt requested.Â  According to the return receipt card, the pleadings were delivered on May 31, 2002, to 116 E. Canal Street, Sumter, SCÂ  29150, and were accepted by Howard Parnell, an employee of the Agencyâ€™s weatherization program.Â  The pleadings were never delivered to Mance, Johnson, or any other person authorized by the Agency to accept service of process.
On July 12, 2002, Montgomery moved for default judgment and requested a damages hearing in the case.Â  According to the cover letter, Montgomeryâ€™s attorney sent the notice of the default hearing to 13 South Main Street, Sumter, SCÂ  29150, the correct address for the Agencyâ€™s main administrative offices.Â  Upon receiving the notice, Rubye Johnson contacted the Agency attorney.Â  
In its brief to this court, the Agency stated that, at the hearing on Montgomeryâ€™s motion for default, her attorney presented (1) proof of service as evidenced by the return receipt signed by Parnell and the cover letter to the Agency, with which the summons and complaint were enclosed; (2) a document purporting to show that, according to the records maintained by the South Carolina Secretary of State, the Agencyâ€™s registered agent information was listed as â€œPrinciple [sic] Office, 116 E. Canal Street, Sumter, South Carolina.â€Â  Counsel for the Agency presented a letter its attorney had received from Johnson, the executive director, averring (1) neither she nor anyone else at the administrative offices had received the pleadings, and (2) the agency had been located at the 13 South Main Street address since the mid-1980s.Â  In the letter, Johnson further stated (1) the Canal Street address where the summons and complaint were mailed was now the parking lot for the Sumter County Public Library; (2) the building that the Agency used at that address had been demolished in the 1970s; (3) Parnell was the director of the Agencyâ€™s weatherization program and his office was located at 316 South Harvin Street, Sumter, South Carolina; and (4) Parnell did not recall signing for any certified mail addressed to the Agency.
On August 27, 2003, the trial court filed an order finding the Agency to be in default.Â  In the order, the trial court also found Montgomery entitled to â€œJudgment by default on all causes of action as plead [sic] in the Complaint, and for all damages set forth in the Complaintâ€ and stated it would set a damages hearing.
At a nonjury damages hearing on August 4, 2004, the trial court awarded Montgomery a judgment of $24,140 against the Agency.Â  The Agency appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, the Agency argues the trial court erred in granting Montgomeryâ€™s motion for default judgment, contending (1) the judgment was void because service of process was ineffective under Rule 4(d)(8) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure in that the delivery was not restricted to the addressee; (2) there was no evidence that Parnell was an officer or manager of the Agency or otherwise authorized to accept service of process on its behalf; and (3) Montgomery herself acknowledged at the damages hearing that she had known for eleven years the Agencyâ€™s main office was on South Main Street, but could not explain why the summons and complaint were sent to the Canal Street address.Â  These arguments, however, when evaluated in conjunction with the record before us, are insufficient to reverse the default judgment.
Rule 4 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, which governs service of process on defendants in civil actions, serves two purposes, one of which is to confer personal jurisdiction on the court over the defendant.[2]Â  â€œObjections to personal jurisdiction, unlike subject matter jurisdiction, are waived unless raised.â€[3]Â  â€œFor good cause shown the court may set aside an entry of default and, if a judgment by default has been entered, may likewise set it aside in accordance with Rule 60(b).â€[4]Â  
â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€[5]Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he appellant has the burden of providing this court with a sufficient record upon which to make a decision.â€[6]
The Agency alleged in its brief that, during the course of the default hearing, it submitted a letter from Rubye Johnson regarding its correct location and Parnellâ€™s status as an employee.Â  The record, however, does not contain a transcript of this hearing.Â  Furthermore, even if we were give the Agency the benefit of the doubt and assume for the purpose of this appeal that it moved to set aside the entry of default and raised these issues to the trial court, neither the order issued pursuant to this hearing nor the order issued after the damages hearing ruled on either of these arguments.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold there is no basis on which we can reverse the default judgment against the Agency.
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issue on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 66 (Ct. App. 1996).
[3]Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 629, 576 S.E.2d 156, 165 (2003).
[4]Â  Rule 55(c), SCRCP.
[5]Â  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).
[6]Â  Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996).

Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 13, 2006Â Â Â

Alan Martin Stewart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
John K. DeLoach, Jr., of Camden, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this appeal, Midfirst Bank argues the master-in-equity erred in declining to exercise subject matter jurisdiction over the bankâ€™s foreclosure action.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Jessie Banks died in September of 2003.Â  On November 14, 2003, the Kershaw County Probate Court took â€œexclusive original jurisdiction over all subject matter related toâ€ the estate and appointed Pierce C. Newman as the estateâ€™s personal representative.Â  
In February of 2004, Midfirst Bank commenced a foreclosure action against real estate owned by the deceased.Â  Meanwhile, the personal representative determined that the real estate needed to be sold in order to pay for funeral expenses, costs of administration, and debts of the estate, so he filed a petition, lis pendens, and a proposed contract for sale with the probate court.Â  On May 4, 2004, Midfirst Bankâ€™s attorney was served with the probate pleadings, together with notification that a hearing on the matter was to be held on May 25, 2004.Â  The attorney neither responded to the petition nor appeared at the hearing.
The probate court issued an order on May 27, 2004, approving the sale and authorizing the proceeds to be disbursed as follows: first, to the payment of funeral expenses; second, to the costs of administration; and third, to the mortgage on the property.Â  After paying the burial and administration expenses, there was only about $15,000 available to Midfirst Bank, an amount which did not satisfy the mortgage.Â  In conjunction with its order, the probate court signed a release, freeing the real estate from the lien of Midfirst Bankâ€™s mortgage.Â  Midfirst Bank did not appeal from the probate court order, and on June 29, 2004, the personal representative closed the sale.Â Â  
Midfirst Bankâ€™s foreclosure action lingered, however, and the matter was referred to a master-in-equity, who held a hearing on July 13, 2004.Â  The master declined to exercise subject matter jurisdiction over the case because the unappealed probate court order disposed of the property and disbursed the proceeds generated from the sale.Â  The master found service of the probate proceedings upon Midfirst Bankâ€™s attorneys was sufficient and any issues it had with regard to the sale of the property should have been raised to the probate court.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 In an action at law referred to a master with direct appeal to the supreme court or court of appeals, the appellate court will correct errors of law but must affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings unless there is no evidence supporting the findings. Â Sea Cabins on the Ocean IV Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 380, 388, 523 S.E.2d 193, 197 (Ct. App. 1999) affâ€™d in result by, 345 S.C. 418, 548 S.E.2d 595 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Midfirst Bank argues it was never properly served with notice of the probate court matter.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to section 62-1-401 of the South Carolina Code (1987), notice of a hearing in the probate court can be served on a partyâ€™s attorney if the party so requests or if the party â€œhas appeared by attorney.â€Â  Here, the personal representative notified Midfirst Bank of the hearing by serving the Korn Law Firm, which was representing the bank in its foreclosure action.Â Â Â Â  Midfirst Bank argues it only authorized the Korn Law Firm to represent it in the foreclosure action, and therefore, service to the law firm in the probate matter was insufficient.Â  We find no merit to this argument.
The Korn Law Firm was hired to collect Midfirst Bankâ€™s debt, and because of that debt, the personal representative had to notify Midfirst Bank of all probate court proceedings relating to the property on which the bank had a lien.Â  Thus, the Korn Law Firmâ€™s representation of Midfirst Bank was not exclusively limited to the proceedings in circuit court, but with all matters affecting the bankâ€™s foreclosure action.Â  We therefore agree with the masterâ€™s finding that service of the probate proceedings upon Midfirst Bankâ€™s attorneys was sufficient.
Midfirst Bank also argues that even though the property was disposed of under the probate laws of South Carolina, it could still be subject to any encumbrances present at the decedentâ€™s death.Â  While section 62-3-1312 of the South Carolina Code (1987) does allow the probate court to sell land subject to any existing lien, that section also allows the court to file a release of the lien.Â  Here, the probate court filed such a release after ordering the property sold.Â  Midfirst Bank never appealed from this order; thus, the order selling the property and releasing it from the bankâ€™s lien is the law of the case.Â  See In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 573 n.3, 544 S.E.2d 854, 858 n.3 (Ct. App. 2001) (explaining that an unappealed decision of a trial court, right or wrong, is the law of the case). Any objections Midfirst Bank has with regard to how the proceeds of the sale should have been disbursed needed to be lodged before the probate court released the property from its lien.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the master-in-equityâ€™s order declining to exercise subject matter jurisdiction is 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Harry C. Wilson, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert Horsey (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order modifying his divorce settlement agreement with his former wife, Bonnie Horsey (Wife).Â  Husband claims the family court did not have jurisdiction to modify the agreement because it was only modifiable with the consent of both Husband and Wife expressed in a writing signed by both.Â  We reverse. 
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on July 1, 1978.Â  The parties separated in 2000 and have since lived separate and apart.Â  On January 24, 2001, the couple entered into a separation and marital settlement agreement (Agreement).Â  On February 6, 2001, the family court approved the Agreement, finding it met the test of reasonableness, and declared that â€œit should be approved and made the order of this Court.â€Â  The Agreement provided it â€œshall not be modified or changed except by mutual consent and agreement of the parties expressed in a writing signed by both.â€Â  The Agreement further provided â€œthe provisions of this Agreement providing for the division and distribution of property, the allocation of responsibility for payment of marital debts, and the provisions for alimony shall be permanent, nonmodifiable, and shall not thereafter be modified by any court.â€Â  Additionally, the Agreement stated â€œany willful failure to perform or fulfill the obligations and responsibilities herein imposed will subject the offending party to a proceeding for contempt of Court.â€Â  
Wife instituted an action for divorce and moved to set aside the Agreement on the grounds of Rule 60, SCRCP.Â  The family court consolidated the divorce action and Rule 60 motion and set the matter for hearing.Â  The parties subsequently agreed to modify the Agreement to settle the Rule 60 motion, but proceeded to a hearing on the divorce.Â  On January 14, 2001, the family court issued an order granting the parties a divorce, incorporating and approving the modifications to the Agreement.Â  Both partiesâ€™ attorneys signed the order on their clientâ€™s behalf.Â  None of the provisions regarding modification were altered.Â  
On July 24, 2002, Husband filed a complaint for contempt, asserting Wife was in material breach of the Agreement.Â  Wife filed a counterclaim asserting it was Husband who had breached the Agreement.Â  A hearing date was set and depositions were scheduled.Â  When the parties arrived for the depositions, they decided to try to reach a settlement before taking the depositions.Â  After approximately two and a half hours of negotiations, the parties agreed to modify the original Agreement to settle the issues raised in their contempt pleadings.Â  Thereafter, the parties engaged the stenographer, who was there to record the depositions, and Wifeâ€™s attorney recited the terms of the settlement aloud for the record.Â  Husbandâ€™s attorney agreed on the record that the modifications, as stated by Wifeâ€™s attorney, were accurate, and both Husband and Wife stated that they agreed to the settlement.Â  The parties also agreed to obtain a court order incorporating the modifications to their Agreement.Â  
The parties did not immediately submit a final consent order to the family court judge to settle the contempt matter.Â  When thirty days passed since the contempt matter was to be heard, the family court judge issued an Interim Final Order.Â  In that order, the family court judge stated that although the parties reached a settlement, certain portions of the settlement required the interaction of third parties, and the he gave the parties thirty days to consummate the agreement so that he could issue a final order.Â  
Over the next few months, the parties tried to reduce the on-the-record settlement to a written order that could be submitted to the family court.Â  However, the parties came to an impasse because Wife took the position that the modifications were final, and Husband contended there were executory provisions in the settlement the parties could not consummate.Â  On June 2, 2004, Wife served Husband with a Motion to Compel Agreement seeking enforcement of the settlement pursuant to the terms set out in the transcript.Â  Wife also advised Husband by letter that depositions would be limited to questions on the enforcement of the Agreement.Â  Husband disagreed with this limitation and stated his intention to seek clarification from the family court if Wife insisted on the limitation.Â  
At an in-camera meeting, the family court judge advised the parties to prepare for â€œfull blown depositionsâ€ on all issues, but told them that if he reached a different conclusion after reviewing the Interim Final Order and the transcript of the on-the-record settlement, he would notify the parties.Â  Before depositions began, the family court found there had been a meeting of the minds which constituted a binding modification of the Agreement.Â  The family court issued a ruling granting Wifeâ€™s Motion to Compel Agreement and a Final Order outlining the modifications of the Agreement pursuant to the terms contained in the on-the-record settlement.Â  
Husband made a motion to reconsider, claiming the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to modify the Agreement, denied his procedural due process rights, and abused its discretion.Â  The family court heard arguments on the matter and, on January 19, 2005, issued an order denying Husbandâ€™s motion to reconsider.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â 
E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992).Â  â€œThe jurisdiction of a court over the subject matter of a proceeding is determined by the Constitution, the laws of the state, and is fundamental.â€Â  Anderson v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 115, 382 S.E.2d 897, 900 (1989) (citations omitted).Â  â€œLack of subject matter jurisdiction may not be waived, even by consent of the parties, and should be taken notice of by this Court.â€Â  Id.Â 

LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband claims the family court lacked the jurisdiction to modify the Agreement of the parties.Â  We agree.
A property and/or an alimony agreement, unambiguously stipulating that the terms may not be may not be altered, binds the court, as well as the
parties, to those terms.Â  Croom v. Croom, 305 S.C. 158, 161, 406 S.E.2d 381, 383 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing
Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 353, 306 S.E.2d 624, 627 (1983)).Â  The family court does not have jurisdiction to modify an agreement by its own authority or at the behest of only one of the parties if the agreement contains language divesting the court of jurisdiction.Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500-01, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Although a written contract may be orally modified, notwithstanding a provision in the contract barring oral modification,
where a contract has been merged into a court order, and the order contains a provision barring oral modification, any oral modification is unenforceable.Â  Messer v. Messer, 359 S.C. 614, 634-35, 598 S.E.2d 310, 321 (Ct. App. 2004).
In the instant case, the Agreement, merged into the family courtâ€™s order, unambiguously provides it can only be modified by mutual consent in a writing signed by both parties.Â  Our review of the record clearly reveals both parties agreed to modifications of the Agreement by voicing their assent on the record, and Husband asserted he â€œabsolutelyâ€ agreed.Â Â  However, this court is bound by language in the partiesâ€™ original Agreement, divesting the family court of subject matter jurisdiction to modify its terms.Â  Because the settlement was not signed by either party, the Agreementâ€™s modification terms were not met.Â  Therefore, the settlement did not constitute a binding modification of the Agreement.Â  Because the family court did not have jurisdiction to modify the Agreement by its own authority, the family court erred in incorporating the modifications contained in the on-the-record settlement in its order.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is 
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gladys J. Haskins, Respondent,
v.
Lynn Ray Tidwell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-164Â Â 
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed March 17, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William T. Geddings, Jr., of Manning, for Appellant.
William Ceth Land, of Manning, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â  Lynn Ray Tidwell (Ray) appeals from an order of the family court finding he entered into a common-law marriage with Gladys J. Haskins (Gladys) and granting Gladys a divorce from Ray.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The parties met in the early 1980â€™s and became involved in a relationship in 1988.Â  Gladys testified that in August 1988, she and Ray went to the beach and Ray purchased wedding rings.Â  According to Gladys, when they came back, Ray told everyone they got married at the beach.Â  Thereafter, the parties lived together until January 5, 2004.Â  During this time, they put their money together, maintained joint checking accounts, and paid bills together.Â  Gladys submitted into evidence a Brendleâ€™s credit card in the name of â€œGladys Tidwellâ€ as well as some checks showing an account listed as â€œGladys J. Haskins or Lynn R. Tidwell.â€Â  The credit card showed it was issued in May 1990 and the checks were written in 1991 and 1992.Â  Gladys also testified she and Ray obtained an automobile insurance policy together, and she submitted insurance cards for the policy showing effective dates of 2003 and 2004.Â  Finally, Gladys submitted into evidence mail she and Ray received in December 2003. One was a Christmas card envelope from Rayâ€™s daughter and son-in-law addressed to â€œRay and Mousey Tidwell.â€[1]Â  The other was from Gladysâ€™ cousin and was addressed to â€œGladys and Ray Tidwell.â€Â  Gladys stated she told people she was in a relationship with Ray and they were â€œlike as one.â€Â  She testified Ray also said they were â€œas one as a coupleâ€ and â€œwere together like one person,â€ and he continued to refer to them this way to other people after 1995.Â  Ray obtained a license plate that read â€œAS ONE,â€ and Ray told Gladys it meant she and Ray were â€œas one person.â€Â  She believed their relationship was the same as marriage.Â  
In March 1991, Ray had a will made out indicating his â€œintent to marry Gladys Haskins at some subsequent date.â€Â  Gladys testified she had a similar will drawn at the time.Â  In August 1991, when Ray was in jail, he asked Gladys to draw up a document indicating she was his common-law wife so they could have conjugal visits.Â  Gladys signed a notarized document stating she and Ray had been living together as common-law husband and wife since June 1988.Â  
On March 5, 1995, Gladys obtained a divorce from Donald Haskins, whom she had married in April 1963 and from whom she had been separated since December 1976.Â  Gladys testified that Ray paid for her divorce because â€œhe was tired of [her] being married to Donald.â€Â  She believed she was common-law married to Ray before her divorce, as well as after her divorce from Donald.Â  Gladys claimed she held herself out as being married to Ray after the divorce and everyone thought they were married.Â  She stated she wore her wedding rings and that Ray also wore his on occasion, continuing to do so after 1995.Â  
Gladys admitted she had filled out paperwork, both before and after 1995, indicating she was single or unmarried.Â  At a social security disability hearing in 1999, Gladys identified Ray as her boyfriend.Â  She also listed Ray as her boyfriend on bank account records in 2003, as well as a loan application in 2004.Â  The record reflects Gladys further identified Ray as her boyfriend during numerous hospital admissions in 1998 and 1999.Â  Gladys testified she listed herself as single because she believed she had to be married with a license and â€œin front of a preacherâ€ or in a church in order to list herself as married on the documents.Â  Gladys denied that she and Ray had lived in separate residences, stating they had â€œalways lived together.â€Â  
Gladys presented the testimony of two others to support her position.Â  Her daughter, Donna Callen, testified that the parties lived together and purchased wedding rings.Â  Donna stated that about ten years ago both Gladys and Ray told her that they had gotten married.Â  She stated that, over the past ten years, she had not heard Ray say â€œdirectlyâ€ that they were married, but Ray referred to Gladys as his wife or his old lady, and he continued to do this until the parties separated.Â  Ray and Gladys participated in family get-togethers, including Fatherâ€™s Day, and he told Donna he loved her like a daughter â€œall the time.â€Â  She further stated her own children called him â€œGrandpa Rayâ€ and that Ray never objected or told the children he was not their grandfather.Â  Donna heard Ray refer to himself and Gladys â€œas one,â€ telling Donna that they would â€œalways be together as one.â€Â  Tina Floyd also testified on behalf of Gladys.Â  She stated that from 1991 to halfway through 1995 Ray, who was a childhood friend of her husband, would come into their store/bar to speak to her husband.Â  When he was there, Tina, referring to Gladys, would ask where his wife or his old lady was and he would answer her.Â  Ray never objected to Tina referring to Gladys as his wife, and he never indicated she was his girlfriend and not his wife.Â  Although Ray himself never used the term â€œwife,â€ he did refer to Gladys as his â€œold lady,â€ which Tina understood to be his wife.Â  
Ray testified he was never married to Gladys and never held himself out as being married to her.Â  He claimed in June 2003, he was living in a garage apartment on the same property as the mobile home where Gladys lived.Â  Ray admitted Gladys stayed with him sometimes, and that he would stay with her when she was ill so he could take care of her, but claimed he usually slept on the couch when she was sick.Â  Ray denied that he paid for Gladysâ€™ divorce in 1995 and testified he did not care if she obtained one.Â  He stated he had a license plate on his vehicle that read â€œAS ONE,â€ but claimed it did not refer to him and Gladys, and meant only that he considered himself as one.Â  Ray also denied ever getting any wedding rings at the beach or giving a wedding ring to Gladys.Â  He stated their relationship continued after Gladysâ€™ divorce in 1995 as it had been prior to the divorce, sharing expenses, having sex, having car insurance together, and him referring to her as his â€œold ladyâ€ on occasion.Â  He further admitted his license plate read â€œAS ONEâ€ after 1995.Â  
The family court determined Gladys met her burden in establishing a common law marriage between the parties.Â  The court found as follows:Â  (1) the preponderance of evidence showed Ray not only knew about Gladysâ€™ divorce from her former husband, but encouraged her to obtain the divorce and helped her pay for it; (2) after the divorce, the parties continued to live together as they did prior to the divorce; (3) the parties lived together from 1988 until January 2004; (4) Ray referred to the couple â€œas oneâ€ and the cohabitation was apparently matrimonial; (5) Ray referred to Gladys as his â€œold ladyâ€ and never took any action to negate the strong presumption in favor of marriage; (6) the parties treated each other as husband and wife; and (7) Gladysâ€™ statements that they were not married referred to her belief that a ceremonial marriage was necessary for them to be legally married and were not made with the idea of negating the presumption of marriage.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The issue of whether a common-law marriage exists is a question of law, and this courtâ€™s review is therefore limited to a determination of whether the trial judgeâ€™s findings are supported by any evidence.Â  Callen v. Callen, 365 S.C. 618, 623, 620 S.E.2d 59, 62 (2005).Â  The question is not what conclusion this court might reach after reviewing the facts, but whether the facts as found by the trial judge are supported by the evidence.Â  Id. at 629, 620 S.E.2d at 65 (Toal, C.J., dissenting); Tarnowski v. Lieberman, 348 S.C. 616, 619, 560 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ray contends the family court erred in holding Gladys sustained her burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence (1) the existence of a new mutual agreement to enter into a common-law marriage after Gladysâ€™ divorce from Donald and (2) the existence of a common-law marriage.Â  He argues the majority of Gladysâ€™ evidence concerns the time period in which she was married to Donald, and that this evidence must be disregarded.Â  He maintains the evidence offered after the impediment to marriage was removed is insufficient to prove a common-law marriage, it fails to show a new agreement between the parties, and that the record is devoid of evidence of a mutual intent of the parties to enter a common-law marriage.Â  He further asserts the evidence he presented is sufficient to overcome any presumption of matrimony.
The party claiming the existence of a common-law marriage must prove the same by the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Callen v. Callen, 365 S.C. 618, 623, 620 S.E.2d 59, 62 (2005); Kirby v. Kirby, 270 S.C. 137, 140, 241 S.E.2d 415, 416 (1978).Â  In South Carolina, a common-law marriage is formed when two parties contract to be married.Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62.Â  Essential to a common-law marriage is a mutual agreement between the parties to assume the relation of husband and wife.Â  Tarnowski v. Lieberman, 348 S.C. 616, 619, 560 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThe fact finder is to look for mutual assent:Â  the intent of each party to be married to the other and a mutual understanding of each partyâ€™s intent.â€Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62.

A party need not understand every nuance of marriage or divorce law, but he must at least know that his actions will render him married as that word is commonly understood.Â  If a party does not comprehend that his â€œintentions and actionsâ€ will bind him in a â€œlegally binding marital relationship,â€ then he lacks intent to be married.Â  A lack of intent to be married overrides the presumption of marriage that arises from cohabitation and reputation.Â  South Carolina does not impose marriage upon a couple merely because they intend to be together forever.

Id. at 626, 620 S.E.2d at 63 (citation omitted).Â Â  
Direct evidence of the requisite intent, such as public declaration by the parties of their entering into a contract of marriage, may not be readily available.Â  Barker v. Barker, 330 S.C. 361, 367, 499 S.E.2d 503, 507 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Thus, no express contract is required.Â  Rather, the agreement may be inferred from the circumstances.Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62.

The difference between marriage and concubinage in the circumstances stated rests in the intent of the cohabiting parties; the physical and temporal accompaniments of the cohabitation may be the same in both cases, but the intent in the two cases is widely apart always.Â  The intent in marriage is usually evidenced by a public and unequivocal declaration of the parties, but that is not necessary; the intent may exist though never public and formally declared; nevertheless the intent must exist.Â  . . .Â  It is true that when the intent has not been formally and publicly declared, . . .Â  it may yet rest in circumstances.Â Â Â Â  

Kirby, 270 S.C. at 140, 241 S.E.2d at 416 (quoting Tedder v. Tedder, 108 S.C. 271, 276, 94 S.E. 19, 20 (1917)).
There is a strong presumption in favor of marriage by cohabitation, apparently matrimonial, coupled with social acceptance over a long period of time.Â  Tarnowski, 348 S.C. at 620, 560 S.E.2d at 440; Barker v. Barker, 330 at 367, 499 S.E.2d at 506; Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 545, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Thus, â€œwhen the proponent proves that the parties participated in â€˜apparently matrimonialâ€™ cohabitation, and that while cohabiting the parties had a reputation in the community as being married, a rebuttable presumption arises that a common-law marriage was created.â€Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62 (citing Jeanes v. Jeanes, 255 S.C. 161, 166-67, 177 S.E.2d 537, 539-40 (1970)).Â  â€œThis presumption may be overcome by â€˜strong, cogentâ€™ evidence that the parties in fact never agreed to marry.â€Â  Id.Â  (citing Jeanes, 255 S.C. at 167, 177 S.E.2d at 540).Â  While an admission of nonmarriage by one party, fortified by strong circumstances, may suffice to overcome the presumption of marriage from cohabitation and reputation, such an admission is insufficient to overcome the presumption where it is shown the admission may well have been made with reference to a ceremonial marriage, and not uttered with the idea of negating the marital status.Â  Owens, 320 S.C. at 545, 466 S.E.2d at 375.
It is well settled, however, when there exists an impediment to marriage, such as one partyâ€™s marriage to a third person, no common-law marriage may be formed, regardless of whether there is any mutual assent.Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62. Our courts have held that a relationship illicit at its inception does not ripen into a common-law marriage once the impediment to marriage is removed.Â  Instead, the law presumes that the relationship retains its illicit character after removal of the impediment.Â  Johns v. Johns, 309 S.C. 199, 201-02, 420 S.E.2d 856, 858 (Ct. App. 1992); Prevatte v. Prevatte, 297 S.C. 345, 349, 377 S.E.2d 114, 117 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  After the impediment is removed, the relationship is not automatically transformed into a common-law marriage, but is presumed to remain non-marital.Â  Callen, 365 S.C. at 624, 620 S.E.2d at 62.Â  In order for the relationship to become marital, â€œâ€˜there must be a new mutual agreement either by way of civil ceremony or by way of recognition of the illicit relation and a new agreement to enter into a common law marriage.â€™â€Â  Id.Â  (quoting Kirby, 270 S.C. at 141, 241 S.E.2d at 416).Â  This new mutual agreement must be shown to exist by the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Kirby, 270 S.C. at 141, 241 S.E.2d at 416.Â  However, such agreement may be gathered from the conduct of the parties.Â  Johns, 309 S.C. at 202, 420 S.E.2d at 858; Prevatte, 297 S.C. at 349, 377 S.E.2d at 117.
Turning to the partiesâ€™ conduct after removal of the impediment to marriage, the record shows that Ray admitted the partiesâ€™ relationship continued after Gladysâ€™ divorce in 1995 as it had been prior to the divorce, where they shared expenses, engaged in sex, obtained car insurance together, Ray referred to Gladys as his â€œold lady,â€ and his license plate read â€œAS ONEâ€.Â  There is also evidence of record that the parties lived together throughout their relationship, that Gladys believed their relationship was the same as marriage and held herself out as being married to Ray after the divorce, â€œeveryone thought [they] were married,â€ that Ray used the phrase â€œAS ONEâ€ on his license plate to refer to them â€œas one personâ€ and continued to refer to them this way to other people after 1995, and that Gladys wore her wedding rings and Ray also wore his on occasion, continuing to do so after 1995. There is further independent evidence of the partiesâ€™ â€œapparently matrimonialâ€ relationship subsequent to the divorce.Â  Two envelopes post-marked December 2003 were addressed to â€œRay and Mousey Tidwellâ€ and â€œGladys and Ray Tidwell.â€Â  Finally, Gladysâ€™ daughter testified Rayâ€™s references to Gladys as his wife or his â€œold ladyâ€ continued up until the time the parties separated, and Tina Floyd testified Ray never corrected her when she referred to Gladys as Rayâ€™s wife.Â  Accordingly, there is some evidence, based on the conduct of the parties, of a new agreement between them to enter into a common-law marriage after the impediment was removed by Gladysâ€™ divorce from Donald in March 1995.Â  Additionally, there is evidence Gladysâ€™ actions in listing herself as unmarried or single and referring to Ray as her boyfriend were based on her belief that a ceremonial marriage was necessary to refer to a marital relationship in legal documentation and these statements were thus made with reference to a ceremonial marriage, not uttered with the idea of negating the partiesâ€™ marital status.
As previously noted, this courtâ€™s review is limited to a determination of whether any evidence supports the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  The question is not what conclusion this court might reach on the issue had it been the fact-finder, but whether the facts as found by the family court are supported by the evidence.Â  Given our limited standard of review, we are constrained to uphold the family courtâ€™s decision in this matter.
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]â€œMouseyâ€ is Gladysâ€™ nickname.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
John J. Sweeney, Appellant,
v.
Doris M. Sweeney, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.
2006-UP-166 
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Catherine E. Fairey and O. Doyle Martin, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Robert M. Rosenfeld, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â John Sweeney (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order, arguing the family court abused its discretion by failing to terminate his alimony obligation to Doris Sweeney (Wife) and in requiring him to take a $200 monthly credit toward his overpayment of alimony.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were divorced in 1976.Â  The parties entered into a separation agreement, incorporated into the divorce order, which provided that Husband pay permanent, periodic alimony in the amount of $1000 per month and provide heath insurance for Wife.Â  
In 1982, Wife petitioned for an increase in alimony, and the court ordered Husband to pay $1400 per month and continue to provide Wife with health insurance.Â  In 1996, Wife again petitioned for an increase in alimony.Â  At that time, Husband lived in a house valued at $700,000 and had assets worth $523,081.Â  The family court found in favor of Wife and increased her alimony to $1700 per month.Â  The family court also provided that when Wife became eligible for Medicare, she was to obtain coverage and Husband would reimburse her for the cost of her Medicare insurance premium and supplement instead of providing private health insurance coverage.Â  After Wife obtained health insurance through Medicare, the amount Husband was required to pay to continue Wifeâ€™s health coverage was reduced from $542 to $197.60.Â  
On February 21, 2003, Husband filed the current action, seeking a termination or reduction of his alimony obligation to Wife.Â  After a hearing on September 7, 2004, the family court issued an order finding there had been a substantial change in circumstances warranting a reduction in alimony.Â  The family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation to $1000 per month effective to the date of filing.Â  
Thereafter, Wife filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion requesting a ruling from the court regarding whether Husband had a continuing obligation to pay for her Medicare supplement and to specify the mechanics of how Husband was to receive credit for the overpayment of alimony.Â  The family court ordered Husband to continue to pay for the Medicare supplement as previously ordered and provided that Husband is entitled to a monthly $200 credit toward his alimony payment until the total overpayment resulting from the retroactivity provision of the final order is paid in full. Â Husband appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in failing to terminate his alimony obligation to Wife.Â  Husband contends his alimony obligation requires him to liquidate his retirement savings, which constitutes an impermissible continuing division of assets.Â  We disagree.Â  
In appeals from family courts, we have jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Bannen v. Bannen, 286 S.C. 24, 26, 331 S.E.2d 379, 380 (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted). Â Questions regarding alimony rest with the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose conclusion will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion. Â Id.
We note that the family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation by $700 per month based on changed circumstances, and Wife has not challenged this ruling.Â  Therefore, we are left to consider whether the family court abused its discretion in failing to terminate alimony.Â  We conclude that the evidence does not justify a complete termination of all alimony support.Â Â Â  
At the time of the hearing, Wife was 70 years old and suffering from various medical conditions, including diabetes and macular degeneration.Â  After the divorce, Wife worked and accumulated retirement assets totaling $265,067.Â  Although Wife was not withdrawing funds from her IRA at the time of the hearing, she testified that she would be required to begin withdrawing funds when she reached the age of 70 Â½ in a few months.Â  Wife lived in a condominium she purchased for $89,900.Â  Her monthly income, including alimony, was $2,702, and she estimated her monthly expenses at $2,704.Â  
Husband voluntarily retired from employment in 1985, at the age of 54. Â Â Â He remarried shortly after his divorce from Wife, and in 1990, he set up a trust which owns all of the assets of his current marriage, including the $250,000 marital home, which is completely controlled by his current wife.Â  At the hearing, Husband testified his only income is a pension and social security totaling $1481 per month, and his only asset is an IRA totaling $277,526.52.Â  He asserted that he had to deplete the principal of his retirement assets in order to support himself and pay alimony, and that theÂ  principal balance of his IRA account was reduced from $523,087 in 1997 to $277,526.52 in 2005.Â  Husband also testified that he cares for his adult daughter, who suffers from severe mental problems and is unable to work, and receives $522 per month in social security benefits.Â  
The family court noted that both parties had reached a point in their lives when their ability to earn income had nearly vanished and their expenses had increased due to medical bills, and, after the reduction in alimony, the parties had nearly equal income.Â  The evidence demonstrates that Wife is in need of financial support from Husband in order to meet her expenses.Â  Because the purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the position of support she enjoyed during the marriage, we find the family court did not err in declining to terminate alimony.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  
Moreover, we find Husbandâ€™s argument that the liquidation of his retirement assets constitutes an impermissible continuing division of assets to be without merit.Â  Husband has an income of $2,300 per month, including social security for his daughter.Â  Although Husband may be required to liquidate his retirement savings in order to support himself and maintain his lifestyle, the purpose of the IRA is to support Husband in his retirement and the family courtâ€™s order does not require him to turn over assets to Wife.Â  The family courtâ€™s order deals solely with Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation and does not constitute a division of marital assets.
Husband next argues the family court erred in requiring him to take a monthly $200 credit toward his alimony obligation until the $19,627.20 overpayments are paid in full.Â  We disagree.
Husband relies on our decision in Walker v. Frericks, 292 S.C. 87, 354 S.E.2d 915 (Ct. App. 1987), to support his position that the family court erred in ordering the $200 monthly offset.Â  In Walker, Walker (wife) brought an action against Frericks (husband) to collect an alimony arrearage in the amount of $10,660, and the family court ordered Frericks to pay the arrearage in $40 monthly installments.Â  Id. at 92, 354 S.E.2d at 919.Â  Based on Frericksâ€™ income and assets, we held that the family court abused its discretion, and we increased the payment on the arrearage to $125 per month.Â  Id. at 93, 354 S.E.2d at 919.Â  
Walker is clearly distinguishable from the case at bar.Â  In Walker, Frericks, the payor spouse, had substantial means to repay Walker at a higher rate, and the debt resulted from an arrearage.Â  Here, Wife is reimbursing Husband for an overpayment of alimony resulting from the courtâ€™s order decreasing Husbandâ€™s monthly alimony obligation.Â  The $200 offset is equitable considering Wifeâ€™s financial situation.Â  The family court decreased Wifeâ€™s alimony from $1,700 to $1000 per month, and Wife will only receive $800 per month until Husband recoups the cost of the overpayment, resulting in a 50% decrease in Wifeâ€™s alimony income.Â  Moreover, there is nothing in the record to indicate Wife was at fault for the two-year delay between the date Husband filed the action and the date the written order was issued.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
