v.
Myron Williams, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-167Â Â Â 
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; Warren Blair Giese, Fifth Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Myron Williams appeals his convictions for criminal sexual conduct with a minor who is at least eleven years of age but less than fourteen years of age, and criminal sexual conduct with a minor who is at least fourteen years of age but less than sixteen years of age, for which he received consecutive sentences of twenty years in prison, suspended on the service of five years probation, and twenty years in prison, respectively.Â  Williams argues the trial court erred in admitting a pornographic video into evidence and erred in failing to grant his motion for a mistrial.Â Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On September 6, 2002, Bridgett Williams (Daughter), a student at Eau Claire High School, was caught partially undressed with a male student in a locker room.Â  Anna Downs, the school guidance counselor, interviewed Daughter about the incident.Â  Daughter told Downs that the last person she had sex with was â€œher daddy,â€ Myron Williams.Â  Downs then called DSS, the school resource officer, and made all the necessary reports. 
In the following days, an investigation corroborated Daughterâ€™s account of abuse by her father.Â  The Richland County Grand Jury indicted Williams on two counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor. 
At trial, Daughter, then sixteen years old, testified that Williams started touching her â€œprivateâ€ when she was eight to ten years old.Â  The sexual contact included oral sex, digital penetration, and sexual intercourse.Â Â Â  Daughter testified the incidents occurred more than once a month and continued until she was fifteen.Â  Daughter also testified, without objection, that during the times of the incidents, they would watch pornographic movies. 
Beverly Conyers, an investigator with the Columbia Police Department, testified she interviewed Daughter on September 6, 2002.Â Â  Daughter informed Conyers that Williams began assaulting her when she was around ten or eleven, the assaults occurred about four times a month, and the assaults were ongoing.Â  Daughter indicated that the last time she had sex with Williams was September 4, 2002.Â Â Â  
Conyers interviewed Williams on September 11, 2002.Â  Williams admitted to having sex with Daughter one time about a year before.Â  
Conyers questioned Williams about a video Daughter stated he had shown her during some of the incidents.Â  Williams informed Conyers that he had an â€œRâ€ rated DVD from Blockbuster entitled â€œCrimes of Passionâ€ in his truck, and he described the cover of the video.Â  The State sought to introduce a synopsis of the video found on Blockbusterâ€™s website and an â€œXâ€ rated copy of the movie matching Williamsâ€™s description.Â  Williams objected to the admission of the video and the synopsis arguing they were irrelevant and prejudicial.Â  The court held both pieces of evidence could be admitted â€œbased on earlier testimony.â€Â  
On cross examination, Conyers was extensively questioned about her investigation and testified that she â€œspoke with [Williamsâ€™s] sister who said heâ€™s a pervert.â€Â  After this testimony, defense counsel asked to approach the bench, and a brief bench conference was held.Â  Defense counsel then made an objection to the statement on the record and made a motion to strike the testimony as nonresponsive.Â  The court sustained the objection and instructed the jury to disregard the statement.Â  The State then asked to discuss the matter outside the presence of the jury.Â  After a brief discussion, the trial court informed defense counsel:

I think you wanted to make a motion for a mistrial. I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s what you still want to do.Â  I will instruct the jury that they should disregard the last statement . . . . Iâ€™ll tell them to disregard the last statement again and let you continue, counsel.Â  Iâ€™m not going to grant a mistrial on that.

Defense counsel responded, â€œThank you.â€Â Â  After a brief recess, the jury was brought back to the courtroom, and the trial resumed.Â Â  
Williams was found guilty of criminal sexual conduct with a minor who is at least eleven years of age but less than fourteen years of age and criminal sexual conduct with a minor who is at least fourteen years of age but less than sixteen years of age, for which he received consecutive sentences of twenty years, suspended on the service of five years probation, and twenty years incarceration, respectively.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                 
Admission of Pornographic Video 
Williams argues the trial court erred in allowing a pornographic videotape into evidence because it was irrelevant, prejudicial, and inadmissible prior bad act evidence.Â  We disagree. 
â€œ[T]he admission of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and absent clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the lower courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Hofer v. St. Clair, 298 S.C. 503, 513, 381 S.E.2d 736, 742 (1989).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.â€Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the wrongly admitted or excluded evidence.â€Â  Id.
â€œAll relevant evidence is admissible.â€Â  State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 142, 591 S.E.2d 646, 651 (Ct. App. 2004) (cert. granted Oct. 10, 2005).Â  â€œRelevant evidenceâ€ is defined as â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œUnder Rule 401, SCRE, evidence is relevant if it has a direct bearing upon and tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in controversy.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 378, 580 S.E.2d 785, 794 (Ct. App. 2003).
We find the video is relevant.Â  Daughter testified that Williams would play â€œpornosâ€ while the sexual assaults occurred.Â  Thus, evidence Williams possessed a movie of a sexual nature during this period tends to make the alleged sexual assaults more probable.Â  
â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE; see also, State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991) (holding relevant evidence may be excluded where its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice). 
The record indicates the pornographic video in question was allegedly viewed during the sexual assaults.Â  Thus, the video is highly probative of the alleged crimes and was properly admitted.Â  Because of the connection between the act and the viewing of the video, we do not find the trial court abused its discretion in admitting the video.Â Â  
Williams contends the evidence of the video was evidence of a prior bad act and improperly admitted to show Williamsâ€™s propensity to commit the alleged crime.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for review because, at trial, Williams never argued the video constituted prior bad act evidence.Â 
See State v. Conyers, 326 S.C. 263, 266, 487 S.E.2d 181, 183 (1997) (explaining that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
II.              
Denial of Motion for Mistrial 
Williams alleges the trial court erred in denying his motion for a mistrial pursuant to prejudicial testimony characterizing Williams as a pervert.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for review.
A party must make a contemporaneous objection to the sufficiency of a curative instruction to preserve alleged error for review.Â  State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 316, 479 S.E.2d 517, 520 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œAn instruction to disregard incompetent evidence or the withdrawal of such evidence usually is deemed to have cured the error in its admission unless on the facts of the particular case it is probable that notwithstanding such instruction or withdrawal the accused was prejudiced.â€Â  State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 262, 268, 227 S.E.2d 306, 309 (1976).Â  Here, Williams failed to object, on the record, to the trial courtâ€™s curative instruction, and thus, this issue is not preserved. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, we find the trial court did not err in admitting the pornographic video.Â  We further find Williams failed to preserve any issue he had with regard to his motion for a mistrial. The decision of the trial court is accordingly 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
Francis T. Draine, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-169
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 22, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry A. Yates, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Frank B. McMaster, John Gregg McMaster, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this legal malpractice action, Larry A. Yates appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Francis T. Draine based on the statute of limitations of section 15-3-535 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1988, Yates and his corporation entered federal bankruptcy.Â  Thereafter, Yates was indicted and arrested for bankruptcy fraud.Â  In 1996, Yates filed a pro se suit in federal court against the federal officials involved in the bankruptcy and criminal prosecution and against Robert Rutland, a former business associate.Â  Yates hired Draine to represent him, and Draine filed an amended complaint on Yatesâ€™s behalf.Â  The amended complaint alleged civil conspiracy, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, negligent or intentional infliction of emotional distress, violation of constitutional rights, conversion, defamation, tortious interference with contractual relations, and malicious prosecution.Â  The complaint was dismissed as to all parties.Â  This was the only instance Draine represented Yates in any proceeding.
In 1997, Rutland brought an action against Yates and Draine over the recently dismissed federal action.Â  Draine received a grant of summary judgment dismissing the entire complaint against him.Â  The causes of action against Yates remained.
After Draine was dismissed, Yates asked Draineâ€™s attorney, Henry Dargan McMaster, to represent him in the November 18, 1999 summary judgment motion in the Rutland action.Â  McMaster ultimately agreed to the limited representation of Yates in the summary judgment hearing.Â  After two continuances, neither of which were requested by McMaster, McMaster learned the case was set for trial on February 28, 2000, so he withdrew from representing Yates as he only agreed to represent Yates at the summary judgment hearing.Â  A formal motion withdrawing as counsel was filed on March 6, 2000.Â  After Yates obtained new counsel, the case went to trial, and a verdict against Yates was returned.
Yates filed this action against Draine in August 2001, alleging negligence/legal malpractice, negligent misrepresentation, and breach of contract arising from Draineâ€™s representation in the federal civil suit filed by Yates in 1996.Â  Draine moved for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations, and the circuit court granted the motion.Â  Yates appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Yates argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Draine based on the statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
Section 15-3-530 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) provides a three-year statute of limitations for legal malpractice lawsuits.Â  Under the discovery rule, the statute of limitations begins to run from the date the injured party either knows or should know, by the exercise of reasonable diligence, that a cause of action exists for the wrongful conduct. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (Supp. 2001); Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 468 S.E.2d 645 (1996).Â  The supreme court has held:

The exercise of reasonable diligence means simply that an injured party must act with some promptness where the facts and circumstances of an injury would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his has been invaded or that some claim against another party might exist. The statute of limitations begins to run from this point and not when advice of counsel is sought or a full-blown theory of recovery developed. 

Mitchell v. Holler, 311 S.C. 406, 412, 429 S.E.2d 793, 799 (1993).Â  Moreover, the standard is objective and not subjective.Â  Berry v. McLeod, 328 S.C. 435, 438, 492 S.E.2d 794, 796 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œThe statute of limitations begins to run at the time the individual has inquiry or constructive notice.â€Â  Id. at 413, 492 S.E.2d at 800.
Yatesâ€™s own testimony clearly establishes that he became completely and fully aware of any alleged malpractice in January 1997.Â  Yates stated in his affidavit:

I was shocked and could hardly believe what all I had uncovered about Attorney Draine from the record of my case at the Clerk of Courtâ€™s office on January 6, 1997.Â  

In his deposition, Yates conceded:

Iâ€™ll establish the fact that in January â€™97 I was certainly aware of the problems we were having.Â  So if you want to establish that for the fact of the statute of limitations, you got it established.Â  

Additionally, Yates sent a letter to Draine in January 1997 complaining of Draineâ€™s performance.Â  Yates was on notice, by his own admission, of a perceived problem with Draineâ€™s representation on January 6, 1997, and should have filed his action within three years of that date.Â  Yates did not file this action until August 1, 2001, almost twenty months after the statute of limitations had run. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Draine is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
        Laura A. Pitts, Respondent
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â James F. Fraley, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-174
Heard February 7, 2006 â€“ Filed March 22, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jim S. Brooks, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Michael Todd Thigpen, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Walters filedan action requesting a recalculation of child support payments to Laura Pitts.Â  The family courtÂ  increased Waltersâ€™ child support obligation retroactive to January 1, 2002, required Walters to pay via wage withholding through the Spartanburg County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office, and ordered Walters to pay Pittsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Walters appeals the family courtâ€™s ruling.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â Â  
FACTS
Michael C. Walters and Laura A. Pitts were divorced under a Joint Bill for Divorce filed in Mississippi on January 18, 2001.Â  Walters and Pitts are the parents of one minor child, William Tyler Walters, who was born December 16, 1996.Â  
Under a Child Support Consent Order (Consent Order) issued by the Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court of Chesterfield County, Virginia on February 7, 2001, Walters and Pitts agreed Walters would pay Pitts $550 per month as child support.Â  Walters and Pitts further agreed the support payments would begin January 1, 2001, and would be â€œby way of payroll deduction.â€ Â In addition, the Consent Order provides: 

The parties stipulate that they are aware of the presumptive amount of child support called for in this case by the Virginia Child Support Guidelines as set forth in Â§ 20-108.2 of the Code of Virginia.Â  The parties further stipulate that the amount of support agreed upon herein is a voluntary downward deviation from said guidelines which shall remain in effect until January 1, 2002.Â  This deviation is agreed upon in order to aid Michael C. Walters in establishing himself in a new residence in Texas.Â  Both parties are aware that either of them may petition the Court for a modification of this order upon a showing of a material change in circumstances.Â  The parties stipulate that a material change of circumstances shall be deemed to have occurred when their agreement to a downward deviation expires January 1, 2002.Â Â Â  

On May 13, 2002, Pitts filed an action in Spartanburg County seeking to modify the amount of child support set in the Consent Order.Â  Although Pitts alleges she did not give her authorization, this action was dismissed under an Order of Dismissal filed January 9, 2003, for lack of personal jurisdiction over Walters.Â  
In June 2003, Walters brought an action in Texas concerning enforcement of visitation.Â  On June 13, 2003, Walters and Pitts entered into an Agreed Order of Enforcement regarding visitation;Â  Pitts was also ordered to pay $4,100 to Walters for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
In May 2003, Pitts filed another action in Spartanburg County, seeking a modification of Waltersâ€™ visitation and an increase in child support.Â  Walters moved to dismiss the action on the ground that the court lacked personal jurisdiction over him.Â  By order dated October 10, 2003, the court concluded it had jurisdiction to hear and determine visitation, but lacked jurisdiction to modify Waltersâ€™ child support obligation.Â  On November 14, 2003, the court issued an order modifying Waltersâ€™ visitation; the order did not address child support.Â  
On December 29, 2003, Pitts filed an action in Texas, where Walters was residing at the time, seeking modification of the Consent Order.Â  Walters then filed this action in Spartanburg, and filed a Motion to Dismiss the Texas action alleging South Carolina was a more appropriate forum.Â  Subsequently, Pittsâ€™ Texas action was dismissed pursuant to a Notice of
Nonsuit.  
Waltersâ€™ complaint in this action was filed on January 30, 2004, and requested a recalculation of child support payments.Â  Walters failed to appear at the scheduled hearing, and the court concluded it would be fair and equitable to both parties for the hearing to be one for temporary relief.Â  Under a Temporary Order filed October 8, 2004, the court: (1) increased Waltersâ€™ child support obligation retroactive to January 1, 2002; (2) concluded Walters owed a total of $7,765 as retroactive child support; (3) increased Waltersâ€™ net monthly child support obligation to $811; (4) directed Walters to provide Pitts with up-to-date financial information and a current address; and (5) ordered Walters to pay Pitts $1,000 for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. 
A final hearing was held on January 19, 2005.Â  Under a Final Order, dated March 11, 2005, the court: (1) recalculated Waltersâ€™ child support obligation pursuant to the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines;[1] (2) held Walters owes Pitts a total child support arrearage of $9,569;[2] (3) required Walters to pay via wage withholding through the Spartanburg County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office; (4) required Walters to repay retroactive child support award and arrearage at the rate of $200 per month; (5) required Walters and Pitts to maintain health insurance coverage on their minor child and divide excess, uncovered medical expenses for their minor child; and (6) ordered Walters to pay $2,150, by way of contribution, for Pittsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
Walters appeals the family courtâ€™s order.Â  Specifically, Walters appeals the award of retroactive child support increases prior to August 15, 2004, and the manner of payment through the court.Â  In addition, Walters requests a credit for excess payments and attorneyâ€™s fees he paid to Pitts. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action on appeal from the family court, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â 
Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 448, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).Â  â€œThe appellate court is not, however, required to ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999) (citation omitted).Â  â€œChild support awards are addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and, absent an abuse of discretion, will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â 
Engle, 343 S.C. at 448, 539 S.E.2d at 714 (citation omitted).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€ Â Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                  Retroactive Child Support
Walters argues the family court erred in increasing Waltersâ€™ child support obligations retroactive to January 1, 2002.Â  We agree the family court erred in retroactively increasing child support to January 1, 2002, but find the facts warrant a retroactive increase to December 29, 2003.Â  
â€œA prior action concerning child support is res judicata only as long as the circumstances existing at the time of the prior action have remained the same.â€Â  Marsh v. Hancock, 288 S.C. 341, 345, 342 S.E.2d 607, 609 (1986) (citation omitted). Â â€œAn order of child support is subject to modification upon the showing of a sufficient change of conditions.â€ Â Hughes v. Hughes, 280 S.C. 388, 390, 313 S.E. 2d 32, 33 (Ct. App. 1984) (citation omitted). Â â€œ[C]hild support is always modifiable upon a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.â€Â  Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 137, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
â€œThe decision to award retroactive child support rests in the sound discretion of the family court.â€Â 
Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 453, 539 S.E.2d 712, 716 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).Â  Section 20-7-933 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides: 

The family court has the authority to enforce the provisions of any decree, judgment, or order regarding child support of a court of this State, including cases with jurisdiction based on the revised Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act, provided that personal jurisdiction has been properly established. This authority includes the right to modify any such decree, judgment, or order for child support as the court considers necessary upon a showing of changed circumstances. No such modification is effective as to any installment accruing prior to filing and service of the action for modification. Additionally, the family court has the right to hold any arrearage in child support in abeyance.

Section 20-7-933 â€œdoes not bar retroactive child support increases in special circumstances where, to do so, would result in serious injustice.â€Â  Harris v. Harris, 307 S.C. 351, 353, 415 S.E.2d 391, 392-393 (1992).Â  The power to award retroactive child support â€œdepends upon the facts and circumstances of each case.â€Â  Wint v. Wint, 310 S.C. 48, 50, 425 S.E.2d 48, 50 (Ct. App. 1992) (citation omitted).
Initially, we find a sufficient change of circumstances existed to warrant a modification of the child support obligation.Â  This action was commenced in January 2004, and the Consent Order specifically provides that a â€œmaterial change of circumstances shall be deemed to have occurred when their agreement to a downward deviation expires January 1, 2002.â€Â  Moreover, the Consent Order was based on a â€œdownward deviation to aid [Walters] in establishing himself in a new residence in Texas,â€ and sufficient time has elapsed to satisfy this basis.Â  In addition, Walters has received a pay raise.Â  
Pursuant to section 20-7-933, the family court may modify a child support obligation without a showing of special circumstances to the date of filing.Â  Indeed, Walters admitted the court may retroactively modify the support obligation to the date of the filing of this action.Â  Thus, because the present action was filed on January 30, 2004, this court needs only to determine whether special circumstances existed to warrant a retroactive modification before that date.Â Â Â  
The family court held special circumstances existed to warrant a retroactive increase to January 1, 2002, mainly because â€œthe fact that [Walters] subsequently filed this action in an effort to deprive the Texas Court of jurisdiction . . . makes it appear [Waltersâ€™] primary motive for asking this Court to dismiss the 2002 and 2003 actions was to avoid having his child support obligation recalculated.â€Â  The family court also noted Walters failed to appear at the originally scheduled hearing and failed to provide his attorney with up-to-date income information.Â  
We find, under the facts of this case, special circumstances do not exist to warrant a retroactive child support increase to January 1, 2002, but special circumstances do exist to warrant a retroactive increase to December 29, 2003.Â  On December 29, 2003, Pitts, for the first time, filed an action seeking an increase in child support in an appropriate jurisdiction.Â  Prior to December 29, 2003, the ultimate cause of delay lies with Pitts; Pitts needed only to file in an appropriate jurisdiction in order to have the child support obligation modified.Â  Based on these facts, no serious injustice can be reasonably construed to warrant a retroactive increase to January 1, 2002, and the trial court committed an abuse of discretion in so finding.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
However, once Pitts filed in an appropriate jurisdiction, Walters became solely responsible for the ensuing delays in modification.Â  The fact that Walters subsequently filed this action in South Carolina, a state where Walters previously contested jurisdiction on two separate occasions, can only be interpreted as an attempt to manipulate the system and delay modification.Â  To allow Walters to benefit from such delay tactics would result in a â€œserious injustice.â€ Harris, 307 S.C. at 353, 415 S.E.2d at 393.[3]Â  
Walters, citing Harris, argues a party must show a â€œfraud upon the courtâ€ to warrant a retroactive child support modification. Â However, Walters misconstrues Harris.Â  In Harris, the court found that the â€œ[f]atherâ€™s failure to disclose his increased earnings from 1987 to 1990 constitutes a special circumstance warranting a retroactive increase.â€ Â Id. at 353, 415 S.E.2d at 393.Â  In Harris, the father failed to make any reference to his brokerage business in his financial declaration, and thus, the support obligation was based upon inaccurate income information.Â  Id. at 352, 415 S.E.2d at 392.Â  Similarly, in this case, Waltersâ€™ delay tactics caused the support obligation paid, since December 29, 2003, to be based upon income information that was inaccurate. Â Â 
Pursuant to the above, we remand to the family court to recalculate Waltersâ€™ total arrears, if any.Â  In the alternative, the family court must give Walters credit for any excess payments.Â  The family court must determine the most appropriate method for either paying the arrears or giving Walters a credit.Â  
II.              
Payment to Clerk of Court 
Walters contends the family court abused its discretion in requiring child support payments to be made through the clerk of court.Â  We disagree. 
In â€œcases in which support orders are issued or modified . . . the income of an obligor is subject to immediate withholding as of the effective date of the order without requirement that an arrearage accumulate.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1315(B)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  However, section 20-7-1315 further provides â€œincome is not subject to withholding if: (a) one of the parties demonstrates and the court finds that there is good cause not to require immediate income withholding; or (b) a written agreement is reached between both parties which provides for an alternative arrangement.â€
The record indicates, pursuant to the Consent Order, Walters has always paid support payments â€œby way of payroll deductionâ€ through the Virginia Department of Social Services.[4]Â  In addition, Walters lives out of state and, as the trial court noted, â€œwage withholding is the most reliable way to ensure that [Walters] pays his child support payments.â€Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not commit an abuse of discretion in requiring Walters to pay child support payments via wage withholding.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
III.          
Attorney Fees and CostsÂ  
Walters asserts the family courtâ€™s awarding of attorneyâ€™s fees to Pitts should be remanded and reconsidered if Waltersâ€™ appeal is successful.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  â€œIn determining whether an attorneyâ€™s fee should be awarded, the following factors
should be considered: (1) the partyâ€™s ability to pay his/her own attorneyâ€™s fee; (2) beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; (4) effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.â€Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  The factors the family court should consider in awarding reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs include: â€œ(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.â€ Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â Â Â  Â 

 The record supports the family courtâ€™s specific findings of fact on the relevant issues.Â  In addition, Walters contributed to the increased fees by causing the Texas action to be dismissed, and failing to appear at the originally scheduled hearing.Â  Although we ruled in Waltersâ€™ favor by reversing the retroactive increase of child support payments from January 1, 2002 to December 29, 2003, this alone is not dispositive of our decision regarding the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Pitts.Â  See 
Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 269, 621 S.E.2d 389, 396 (Ct. App. 2005) (declining to vacate Wifeâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees even though appellate court ruled in favor of Husband on several issues when court ruled for Wife on other issues, Husband failed to comply with terms of Property Settlement Agreement, and family court properly considered other requisite factors).Â  Thus, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Pitts.Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the family court committed an abuse of discretion in retroactively increasing Waltersâ€™ child support obligation to January 1, 2002.Â  We hold Waltersâ€™ child support obligation should be increased retroactive to December 29, 2003.Â  We further find the family court did not abuse its discretion in requiring Walters to pay child support through the clerk of court.Â  We also find Pitts is entitled to an award for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We remand to the family court to recalculate Waltersâ€™ child support obligation based on the foregoing.Â  The decision of the family court is accordingly
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The court increased Waltersâ€™ net monthly child support obligation to $967 through March 15, 2005; thereafter, Waltersâ€™ net monthly child support obligation was set at $904 because the parties agreed the support obligation should be reduced when Waltersâ€™ new child is born in late March.Â  
[2] This figure was arrived at by combining $8,723 as retroactive child support ($7,765 that Walters was directed to pay as retroactive child support under the October 8, 2004 Temporary Order, and $958 as additional arrearage accumulated after the Temporary Hearing) with the increased support payments based on Waltersâ€™ up-to-date financial information retroactive to August 15, 2004.Â  
[3] We note Pittsâ€™ voluntary dismissal of the Texas action should not be held against her because she was attempting to expedite modification.Â  
[4] In Virginia, orders for wage withholding require the employer of the obligor to send the withheld amount to the Virginia Department of Social Services who then disburses the funds to the obligee.Â  See Va. Code Ann. Â§ 20-79.1(2005).Â

title: Bass v. Bass
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cheryl Bass, Appellant,
v.
Charles Bass, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-175
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 28, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Daphne A. Burns, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellant.Â  
Charles Bass, of Georgetown, for Respondent.
Joe Michael Crosby, of Georgetown, for Guardian Ad Litem.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cheryl Bass (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order in her divorce action against Charles Bass (Husband).Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[1]Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in March of 1985.Â  The parties have a minor daughter and an emancipated son.Â  The family lived at the marital residence in Georgetown until October of 2002, when Wife left with the daughter and moved to another of the partiesâ€™ Georgetown residences.Â  
The family court granted the parties a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery and awarded Wife custody of and support for the partiesâ€™ daughter; awarded sixty percent of the marital estate to Husband and forty percent to Wife; ordered the parties to split the marital credit card debt 50/50; awarded Wife $850 per month in alimony; awarded Wife $7,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees; and required Husband to maintain medical insurance for the daughter.Â  
Wife filed a motion to reconsider.Â  Prior to the courtâ€™s decision on the motion, Wife moved to amend on the ground of after-discovered evidence of Husbandâ€™s adultery, asserting she found explicit photographs of Husbandâ€™s paramour.Â  Wife requested the court consider the evidence in conjunction with her motion to reconsider the equitable distribution award.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s motion to amend and her motion to reconsider.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 542, 615 S.E.2d 98, 103 (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Motion to Amend the Motion to Reconsider
Wife contends the family court erred in denying her motion to amend her motion to reconsider and in not reconsidering Husbandâ€™s misconduct in light of the after-discovered evidence.Â  We disagree.
To obtain a new trial based on after-discovered evidence, a movant must establish that the evidence:Â  (1) will probably change the result if a new trial is granted; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not have been discovered before the trial; (4) is material to the issue; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 217, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  See also Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  The decision to grant a new trial based on after-discovered evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 151, 591 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Wife argues the newly discovered pictures of Husbandâ€™s paramour entitle her to reconsideration and further argues the family court did not give weight to Husbandâ€™s misconduct in apportioning the marital estate.Â  The family court found the new pictures would â€œprobably not cause the Court to alter its prior decisionâ€ and it appeared to be offered â€œmerely for the purpose of impeaching a prior witness and is cumulative.â€Â  
We find no abuse of discretion by the family court, as the evidence was cumulative to other evidence of Husbandâ€™s adultery and the court clearly considered the adultery in its final order.Â  As evidenced by granting a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery and in awarding alimony after assigning Husband â€œthe fault of the dissolution of this marriage,â€ the family court took Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct into account in its final order.Â  Because the family court considered Husbandâ€™s misconduct, we find no abuse of discretion.
II.Â  Savings Bonds
Wife next contends the family court erred in not including the partiesâ€™ savings bonds in the marital estate.Â  We disagree.
Approximately two months prior to the partiesâ€™ separation, Husband cashed over $12,000 in savings bonds without Wifeâ€™s knowledge.Â  The bonds were intended to fund the childrenâ€™s college education.Â  Husband testified he believed the money was not necessary for the children because the partiesâ€™ son dropped out of high school and was not attending college and the South Carolina lottery system would pay for their daughterâ€™s education.Â  Husband allegedly gave the money to his son from a previous marriage.Â  
Subject to certain exceptions, the marital estate includes â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2005).Â  To apportion property that is no longer in the marital estate, there must be evidence of willful misconduct, bad faith, or intention to dissipate marital assets.Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 232-33, 512 S.E.2d 539, 544 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Gifts to others during the marriage, absent proof of fraud, are not marital property for purposes of equitable distribution.Â  Panhorst v. Panhorst, 301 S.C. 100, 105-06, 390 S.E.2d 376, 379 (Ct. App. 1990).
Husband cashed the bonds and gifted the proceeds to his son prior to the time Wife left the marital home.Â  We find the savings bonds do not meet the definition of â€œmarital property,â€ and there is insufficient evidence in the record to conclude that Husband cashed the bonds to intentionally dissipate marital funds in contemplation of marital litigation.Â  We discern no error.
III.Â  Marital Home
Wife contends the court erred in awarding the marital home to Husband.Â  We disagree.
The marital home is merely a share of the total marital estate.Â  Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 291, 617 S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005).Â  The disposition of the residence in the context of equitable distribution of the marital estate is largely within the discretion of the family court.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 202, 612 S.E.2d 707, 718 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
As part of the equitable distribution, the family court awarded the marital home in Georgetown to Husband and two other Georgetown homes owned by the parties to Wife.Â  Wife requested the marital home based on the fact the daughter had been raised there and that she would be unable to attain comparable housing.Â  However, at the time of the final divorce decree, Wife and daughter had been living in one of the other Georgetown properties for approximately two years.Â  There is nothing in the record to indicate a problem for Wife or daughter under their current living conditions.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the courtâ€™s award of the marital home to Husband.
IV.Â  Life Insurance
Wife contends the court erred in failing to require Husband to maintain life insurance to secure the payment of child support.Â  We disagree.
A party requesting life insurance as security for alimony or child support must show â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ for such an award.Â  Wooten, 364 S.C. at 553, 615 S.E.2d at 108.Â  Special circumstances include major health problems of the payor spouse or a payor spouseâ€™s inability or failure to pay his support obligation.Â  Id. at 550, 615 S.E.2d at 107.Â  In this case, no special circumstances exist to require Husband to maintain life insurance to secure his child support obligation.Â  Therefore, we find no error by the family court.
V.Â  Other Issues Affecting Equitable Distribution 
Wife contends the family court erred in considering her failed businesses and â€œexcessive credit card spendingâ€ in its distribution of the marital estate.Â  Wife further contends the family court erred in not assessing the amount of marital debt as of the beginning of the marital litigation, thereby failing to credit her for payments she made to reduce the credit card debt during the pendency of the action.Â  We find no reversible error. 
As to the Wifeâ€™s businesses and spending, we recognize that â€œpoor business decisions, in and of themselves, do not warrant a finding of marital â€˜misconduct,â€™ and . . . there must be some evidence of willful misconduct, bad faith, intention to dissipate marital assets, or the like, before a court may alter the equitable distribution award for such misconduct.â€Â  McDavid v. McDavid, 333 S.C. 490, 496, 511 S.E.2d 365, 368 (1999).Â  The family court may, however, consider spending habits.Â  Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 59, 606 S.E.2d 489, 496 (Ct. App. 2004) (distinguishing McDavid as more applicable to cases involving business expenditures as opposed to mere spending habits, which may be considered by the family court).Â  In the final divorce decree, the family court noted its consideration of Wifeâ€™s â€œexcessive credit card spendingâ€ and â€œfailed businessesâ€ in determining the equitable distribution of marital assets.Â  The court also found â€œthe accumulation of marital assets has been realized mainly by the [Husbandâ€™s] superior income during the marriage.â€Â  While consideration of Wifeâ€™s failed businesses may have been improper without a finding of Wifeâ€™s bad faith, we find no reversible error as we find the overall apportionment of the marital estate to be equitable.Â  
Because we find the overall apportionment of the marital estate to be equitable, we likewise find no error in the courtâ€™s apportionment of the marital debt.Â  Wife asserts that between the time of filing and the final divorce hearing, she paid $15,398.10 towards the credit card debt and reduced the total debt by approximately $9,400.Â  Wife contends she should be reimbursed for a percentage of these payments.Â  In equitably dividing the marital estate, the family court must â€œgive weight in such proportion as it finds appropriateâ€ to â€œexisting debts incurred by the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (13) (Supp. 2005).Â  The words â€œin such proportion as it finds appropriate,â€ as used in the statute, accord much discretion to the trial judge in providing for the payment of marital debts as a consideration in the equitable division of the marital estate.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 97, 103, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995). On review, this court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  Id.Â  Because we find the overall apportionment to be fair, the fact that this court might have apportioned the estate differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  We therefore affirm the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment of the marital estate.Â  
VII.Â  Private Investigator and Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife contends the family court erred in not awarding her separate suit costs for the private investigator fees and in not awarding her reasonable attorney fees.Â  We agree as to the private investigator fees and reverse that portion of the courtâ€™s order.Â  
As a result of finding repeated listings of another womanâ€™s phone number on her phone bills, Wife hired a private investigator to investigate Husbandâ€™s fidelity.Â  This investigation was undertaken approximately a month and a half after the parties separated and involved two private investigators.Â  Once the investigators were able to document evidence of Husbandâ€™s infidelity, they ceased the investigation and tendered bills for approximately $3,500 to Wife.Â  
The court found private investigator fees to be a proper area of consideration, but stated it had already considered these fees in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court is authorized to order payment of suit money to either party in a divorce.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-120 & -130 (1985 & Supp. 2005).Â  Reimbursable expenses include reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in obtaining evidence of a spouseâ€™s infidelity.Â  See Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  Because Wife proved Husbandâ€™s adultery, we find the family court erred in failing to award Wifeâ€™s private investigator fees, which were incurred to prove Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  We therefore award Wife $3,500 to be paid by Husband within ninety days of this opinion.
As to the attorneyâ€™s fees, we find no error.Â  Wife accrued $17,410.22 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court ordered Husband to pay $7,500 to Wife for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife asserts that the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was unreasonable because the family court failed to consider all of the proper factors.Â  
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and should not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Doe v. Doe, 319 S.C. 151, 157, 459 S.E.2d 892, 896 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The family court is given broad discretion in this area.Â  Id.Â  The family court, in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
The family court considered the relevant factors in making an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and in setting the amount.Â  The court considered the beneficial results obtained by Wife, Husbandâ€™s fault in the divorce, and the financial situation of the parties.Â  We find no abuse of discretion by the family court and affirm the award of $7,500 for Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.
 AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.Â  
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

Heard February 8, 2006 â€“ Filed March 28, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
Alexander Blair Cash, of Charleston, for Appellant.
George E. Counts, Kelvin M. Huger, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Marvin Pasley (Husband) appeals a family court order asserting the court erred in determining four vehicles purchased by Husband after the date of filing and income earned by Husband from his sole proprietorship after the date of filing constituted marital property, in failing to reduce the value of the marital estate by the amount of outstanding tax debt, and in awarding retroactive alimony.Â  We affirm in part and remand in part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Carrie Pasley (Wife) were married on May 23, 1987 and separated on May 27, 1999.Â  Shortly after the marriage, Husband began serving as a Minister in the African American Episcopal Church.Â  In 1989, Wife was diagnosed with sarcoidosis.Â  Wife worked as a dental hygienist at the time the parties married and continued to work in this field for approximately twenty years, until Wife ultimately became disabled.Â  Wife also performed various functions in her role as a ministerâ€™s wife.Â  In 1995 Pasleyâ€™s Mortuary was opened, with Husband as the sole-proprietor of the business.[1]Â  Wife began working at the funeral home business in 1994, prior to its opening, and continued to work there until the latter part of 2000.Â  In addition to the sarcoidosis, and a stroke she suffered in 1999, Wife suffers from depression, anxiety disorder, sleep apnea, chronic sinusitis, a spastic colon, acid reflux, a hiatal hernia, and damaged lungs.Â  
On March 21, 2001, Wife filed a complaint seeking, among other things, a divorce based on the partiesâ€™ one-year separation, alimony, equitable distribution, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband answered and counterclaimed for a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Following a hearing in April 2001, the family court issued a temporary order awarding Wife $600 per month in alimony and temporary attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Because the trial began in December of 2003 and did not conclude until March 2004, the family court issued an interim order on December 19, 2003 increasing Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation to $1,400 per month based on Husbandâ€™s stipulation to his greater income than reported on his financial declaration filed in January 2003.Â  
At the conclusion of the hearing on March 16, 2004, the family court judge found Husband â€œhas lied to this court and tried to hide income.â€Â  The court ordered that assets in a First Citizens account be frozen, and prohibited the use of the account until further order of the court.Â  
On April 1, 2004, the family court issued its final order granting Wife a divorce based on one yearâ€™s separation.Â  In its order, the court found Husband secreted approximately $192,000.00 in a bank account which Husband â€œrefused to disclose or discuss during the pendency of this litigation,â€ and which was only discovered by Wife the day before the last day of trial.Â  The family court found Wife was completely disabled.Â  It further held, while Husband claimed on the last day of trial that he earned only $20,000 a year as a minister and profit of $13,142 a year from the funeral home business, Husbandâ€™s testimony was incredible, and based on Husbandâ€™s receipt of over $70,000 in cash from the funeral business in 2003, as well as the money in the First Citizens account, Husband was earning in excess of $80,000 a year for the past three years.Â  The family court therefore determined Wife was entitled to permanent, periodic alimony in the amount of $1,900 a month, as well as $42,300 in back alimony from the time of filing.Â  The court further found that the partiesâ€™ marital property consisted of the following:Â  (1) personal effects, which were divided by agreement of the parties; (2) the marital home with a net equity of $63,184; (3) Pasleyâ€™s Mortuary with a net equity of $66,100; (4) Husbandâ€™s retirement account valued at $22,330.98; (5) several bank accounts amounting to $55,100; and (6) a First Citizens account with a balance of approximately $192,000.Â  The court awarded the marital home to Wife, the funeral business to Husband, and ordered a 50% division of the remaining marital assets.Â  The court further awarded Wife the entire amount of her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs of $22,420.Â  In addition to the final order, the family court issued an order in June 2004, holding Husband in contempt of court for failing to disclose the existence of the First Citizens account.Â  Thereafter, Husband made a motion to alter or amend the judgment.[2]Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has Â Â  authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002). Â This broad scope of review does not, however, require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Neither are we required to ignore the fact that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                  Marital Property
Husband first claims the family court erred in determining what assets constitute the marital estate.Â  He raises two issues in this respect.Â  Husband asserts error in the inclusion of four vehicles valued at $30,300 that were purchased for the funeral home after the date of filing.Â  He also asserts error in the inclusion of monies in the First Citizens account beyond the initial deposit of $63,432.
Marital property is generally defined as all real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation, regardless of how legal title is held.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2005).Â  For purposes of equitable distribution, the value of marital property is thus the value of the property at the time of the commencement of the marital litigation.Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 292-93, 609 S.E.2d 821, 834 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, both parties are entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation that occurs to marital property after separation but before divorce.Â  Id. at 293, 609 S.E.2d at 834.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Vehicles
Husband presented evidence that he purchased the vehicles in 2002 and 2003, after Wife commenced this divorce proceeding on March 21, 2001.Â  He contends, because it is uncontested the vehicles were all purchased after the date of filing, they are clearly nonmarital and should not have been included in the marital estate.Â  We disagree.
The family court found the funeral home business was a marital asset owned by Husband and Wife.Â  In determining the value of the funeral home, the family court found it included (1) $100,000 for the land and building, (2) $3,800 for furniture, fixture and equipment, (3) $30,300 for the four vehicles, based on Husbandâ€™s appraised value, and (4) an outstanding mortgage of $68,000, for a net equity in the business of $66,100.Â  On appeal, Husband asserts the family court erred in including the $30,300, as the vehicles were not owned at the date of filing of marital litigation and were therefore nonmarital property.Â  Wife counters that the newly purchased vehicles only replaced similar assets already owned by the business before filing.Â  We find no error in the inclusion of these vehicles in the marital estate.Â  
First, there is evidence of record that clearly shows Husband routinely purchased vehicles for use in the business.Â  He testified he had purchased about five or six hearses alone in the past, and stated he had never been able to purchase brand-new hearses, but only used ones, and after the old ones stopped running, he would â€œget ridâ€ of them.Â  Further, the testimony of record shows there was a previous appraisal showing a value of $15,375 for funeral home vehicles, which Husband testified was for older vehicles than those on the present appraisal, and the $15,375 figure was â€œa good faith estimate . . . at that time.â€Â  Husband also admitted that â€œa lot of the cash that [he] pulled out of the business was to purchase vehicles.â€Â  While there is no indication in the testimony as to when the vehicles on this previous appraisal were purchased,[3] there is sufficient evidence for the court to conclude that the funeral home has always operated with the use of limousines and hearses.Â  Finally, common sense dictates that the business could not have operated without the use of support vehicles.Â  Therefore, we agree with Wife that the vehicles included in the value of the business were, at the very least, replacement vehicles.Â  Further, we find any appreciation in the business resulting from the addition of the new vehicles was properly included in the marital estate.Â  See Hatfield v. Van Epps, 358 S.C. 185, 194, 594 S.E.2d 526, 531 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œ[T]he parties to domestic litigation are entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation in marital assets occurring after separation but before divorce.â€); Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 159 n.8, 591 S.E.2d 654, 661 n.8 (Ct. App. 2004) (recognizing that â€œpassive post-filing changes in the appreciation or depreciation of marital assets may be considered by the family court in determining an equitable apportionment of the marital estate.â€); Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 228, 512 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIt is an unfortunate reality that, given the volume of cases handled by our family courts, there often is a substantial delay between the commencement of an action and its ultimate resolution.Â  Thus, it is not unusual for the value of marital assets to change, sometimes substantially, between the time the action was commenced and its final resolution.Â  In such a case, the family court has the ability to consider the post-filing appreciation or depreciation when valuing and apportioning the marital estate.â€).
B.Â Â Â Â Â  First Citizens Account
The issue concerning the secreted account is more complicated.Â  The record shows the final hearing on the partiesâ€™ divorce was held over several days in December 2003, January 2004, and March 2004.Â  During the hearing in December, Husband apparently did not appear for medical reasons.Â  When the hearing continued in January 2004, Husband appeared and testified on his own behalf.Â  Husband claimed, that for tax year 2001, his tax return reflected the funeral business had net earnings of only $3,140.Â  Husband further maintained his salary as a minister in 2001 was approximately $20,000.Â  Husband testified that in tax year 2002, his church salary dropped when he was assigned to another church and he earned between $379 and $500 a week during that time.Â  He claimed the funeral business netted a profit of only $6,093 in 2002, and that he put all of that money back into the business.Â  Husband testified he had â€œ[n]o other income from anywhere.â€Â  Husband also claimed he had approximately $359 in his personal account at First Federal, and he did not have any personal funds in any other account.Â  
The trial resumed on March 16, 2004, with Husband still on the stand.Â  Husband admitted, that after his initial cross-examination, he filed an amended tax return for 2002 reflecting earnings of $13,142 for the funeral business during that tax year.Â  During redirect examination, Husband disclosed the existence of another account.Â  Counsel asked Husband if he knew someone by the name of Oneil Wilder.Â  Husband testified Wilder was a friend of his, and stated he handled some of Wilderâ€™s business affairs.Â  When asked if he handled an account for Wilder, Husband stated Wilder had an account with Husbandâ€™s name on it.Â  When asked if the money in the account belonged to Wilder, Husband claimed part of the money was Wilderâ€™s, and that Wilder â€œput me down as a signer for it.â€Â  Husband claimed both his and Wilderâ€™s money was deposited into the account, he did not know what money was his and what money belonged to Wilder, and he believed Wilder deposited around $80,000 into the account.Â  When asked how the account was started, Husband maintained that Wilder put around $80,000 in the account originally, and that Husband did not put anything in there at that time, but he periodically made deposits into the account.Â  Husband stated he did not know the exact amount of money in the account at that time.Â  On cross-examination, Husband acknowledged he made various deposits into the account and wrote numerous checks out of the account.Â  Husband maintained he wrote many of the checks to pay funeral business bills.Â  He claimed at least one of the deposits made into the account was from money he took out of the funeral home account.Â  When asked where he obtained the money that he deposited into the First Citizens account, Husband stated he had worked since he and Wife separated, implying the money deposited into this account was from his post-separation earnings.Â  
On April 1, 2004, the family court issued its final order finding the First Citizens account was a marital asset that was to be equitably divided.Â  The court included the approximately $192,000 in the account in the marital estate and found the marital estate should be divided equally between the parties.Â  On this date, the family court also held a hearing on Husbandâ€™s Citation for Contempt.Â  Thereafter, on June 22, 2004, the family court issued its order finding Husband in contempt of court based on his willful testimony regarding and his nondisclosure of the First Citizens account.Â  The court fined husband $1,500 and ordered him incarcerated for six months, with the detention held in abeyance conditioned upon Husbandâ€™s performance of three hundred hours of community service.Â  The record does not contain any transcript from the contempt hearing.
On April 12, 2004, Husband filed a motion to alter or amend the final order of divorce.Â  In that motion, Husband argued, among other things, that the family court erroneously included monies from the First Citizens account that were acquired by him as income after the date of filing of marital litigation.Â  While Husbandâ€™s motion is included within the record before us, there is no transcript from any hearing on the motion, nor is there any order from the family court showing disposition of the motion. 
On appeal, Husband alleges that the First Citizens account, with a balance of $192,053, should not have been considered as marital property beyond the $63,432 initially used to open the account a few days after Wife filed for divorce.Â  He asserts the account included his income earned after the date of filing, and that it was his earnings and savings that made the account grow to a balance of $192,053.Â  Thus, he contends that $128,621 of the total balance in the account constitutes nonmarital earnings and this amount should be deducted from the marital estate.Â  Wife counters that the $128,621 is either marital property, or it is non-marital property subject to equitable apportionment by virtue of Husbandâ€™s actions which transmuted it into marital property, or that she is entitled to a special equity in the $128,621.Â  Wife does not explain why the $128,621 is marital property, but generally argues that she is entitled to equitable distribution of this amount because she made significant contributions to the business and because Husband used $63,432 in marital assets to continue to operate the funeral business, thereby allowing the accumulation of $128,621 more in the account.Â  
Husband concedes that it was reasonable for the family court to conclude the initial deposit of $63,432 in the account was marital.Â  The only evidence of record before us as to the source of the other deposits is from husbandâ€™s testimony that at least one deposit of $3,000 came out of the funeral home account, and Husbandâ€™s general testimony that other deposits resulted from his work in the business.Â  However, Husband admittedly perjured himself during his testimony and his credibility is, at the very least, suspect.
The family court did not explain why it determined the entire $192,000 account was marital property.Â  Based on the record before us, it is impossible for this court to determine whether the entire account was found to have been marital based upon the source of the initial deposit as well as the source of subsequent deposits, whether the court determined the initial deposit was marital and the rest of the account was transmuted into marital property by virtue of Husbandâ€™s commingling of funds, or whether the court had some other basis for finding the entire account was marital.Â  While the Wife asserts, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(5) (Supp. 2005),[4] she is entitled to â€œany increase in value in nonmarital property . . . result[ing] directly or indirectly from [her efforts] during the marriageâ€ and that a special equity was thereby created in the $128,621, there was no finding by the family court to support this argument.Â  Additionally, the $128,621 would not qualify as an increase in value of nonmarital property, as the family court determined the entire account was marital.[5]
It is uncontested the initial deposit is marital property.Â  It is also clear at least some portion of the initial deposit generated interest to increase the account.Â  Thus, wife is undoubtedly entitled, at a minimum, to an equitable share in the initial deposit and any appreciation resulting directly from the initial deposit in the form of interest.Â  See Hatfield v. Van Epps, 358 S.C. 185, 194, 594 S.E.2d 526, 531 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œ[T]he parties to domestic litigation are entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation in marital assets occurring after separation but before divorce.â€)Â  However, there is an insufficiency or paucity of evidence and rulings in the record for this court to determine the basis of the family courtâ€™s classification of the entire asset as marital property.Â  Accordingly, we remand this issue to the family court for a determination of what portion of the total account is marital and what portion, if any, is income of the Husband that would not be subject to equitable apportionment, with leave for the court to take additional testimony on the source and use of the funds in this account.Â  The family court shall exclude any income in the account attributable to earnings by Husband after the date of filing. Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
II.              
Tax Debt 
Husband claims the family court erred in failing to reduce the value of the marital estate by the amount of outstanding tax debt resulting from his filing of amended tax returns.Â  He asserts the amended returns revised his taxable income resulting in tax liabilities of $29,786 for tax year 2000, $30,623 for tax year 2001, and $34,408 for tax year 2002.Â  Husband argues the family court was required to consider and apportion the marital debt in conjunction with its apportionment of the assets.Â  He maintains the family court should have equally divided the marital tax debt, which included $29,786 for the 2000 tax year and a pro-rata share of $30,623 from tax year 2001, which should be computed as of the date of filing.Â  
â€œMarital debt, like marital property, must be specifically identified and apportioned in equitable distribution.â€Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 546, 615 S.E.2d 98, 105 (2005).Â  â€œMarital debt should be divided in accord with the same principles used in the division of marital property and must be factored into the totality of equitable apportionment.â€Â  Pirayesh v. Pirayesh, 359 S.C. 284, 300, 596 S.E.2d 505, 514 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In apportioning the marital estate, the family court â€œmust give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriateâ€ to â€œliens and any other encumbrances upon the marital property, which themselves must be equitably divided, or upon the separate property of either of the parties, and any other existing debts incurred by the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2005); Wooten, 364 S.C. at 546, 615 S.E.2d at 105.Â  If the family court finds a debt was not incurred for marital purposes, it need not be factored into the courtâ€™s equitable apportionment of the marital estate, and the court may require payment by the spouse who created the debt for nonmarital purposes.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 97, 103, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Pirayesh, 359 S.C. at 300, 596 S.E.2d at 514.Â  â€œ[T]he words â€˜in such proportion as it finds appropriate,â€™ as used in Â§ 20-7-472, accord much discretion to the trial judge in providing for the payment of marital debts as a consideration in the equitable division of the marital estate.â€Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. at 103, 463 S.E.2d at 324.Â  On review, the appellate court will look to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  Id.  
We agree with Husband that the family court was required to consider and apportion any marital debt in conjunction with its apportionment of the assets.[6]Â  However, we disagree with Husbandâ€™s assertion that the family court was required to equally divide the tax obligation.Â  See Pirayesh, 359 S.C. at 300, 596 S.E.2d at 514 (wherein this court found no error in the family courtâ€™s failure to equally split the partiesâ€™ debts between them).Â  Rather, the family court has much discretion in apportioning the debt in such proportion as it finds appropriate.Â  We further note, while the initial tax obligation for 2000 and the portion of 2001 prior to filing may have been incurred for the joint benefit of the parties, the same cannot be said of the penalties and interest assessed on the tax obligations.Â  Rather, penalties and interest were incurred, not for the benefit of the marriage, but because of Husbandâ€™s failure to initially file a correct return reflecting his true income.Â  We thus find any penalties and interest should be the sole responsibility of Husband.Â  Accordingly, we remand this matter to the family court to determine what tax debts were incurred for the benefit of the marriage and to apportion any such debt consistent with this opinion.[7]Â Â Â  
III.          
Retroactive Alimony 
Finally, Husband complains the family court erred in awarding Wife retroactive alimony because the award constituted a double recovery for Wife.Â  He argues the family court found he made in excess of $80,000 based upon evidence of his receipt of over $70,000 in cash from the funeral business in 2003, as well as money deposited in the First Citizens account.Â  Accordingly, the court concluded it was appropriate to relate Husbandâ€™s receipt of this income back to the time of filing, and calculated back alimony due of $42,300.Â  Husband asserts the family court implicitly held his earnings after the date of filing constituted a marital asset subject to division and additionally required Husband to pay back alimony out of these same funds.Â  He thus contends it was error for the court to award retroactive alimony based on these earnings while also treating the $128,621 earned income in the First Citizens account as a marital asset, as this amounts to a double recovery to Wife.Â  Because we have remanded the issue of the First Citizens account to the family court with instructions to exclude any income in the account that was earned by Husband after the filing date, any of the complained of double recovery by the Wife will be eliminated.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART.Â  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]The business is referred to as both Pasleyâ€™s Mortuary and Pasleyâ€™s Funeral Home throughout the transcript.Â  
[2]There is no evidence in the record that the family court ever ruled on this motion.
[3]The testimony regarding the $15,375 appraisal refers to Plaintiffâ€™s Exhibit 12, which is not included in the record on appeal.Â  We note that the burden is upon appellant to provide a sufficient record from which this court can make an adequate review.Â  See Wint v. Wint, 310 S.C. 48, 50, 425 S.E.2d 48, 50 (Ct. App. 1992). 
[4]This code section provides â€œ[t]he term â€˜marital propertyâ€™ as used in this article means all real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . ., except the following, which constitute nonmarital property: . . . (5) any increase in value in nonmarital property, except to the extent that the increase resulted directly or indirectly from efforts of the other spouse during marriage.â€
[5]We note in Cannon v. Cannon, 321 S.C. 44, 467 S.E.2d 132 (Ct. App. 1996), this court determined where one spouse used marital funds to purchase property after the commencement of marital litigation, the family court properly awarded the other spouse a special equity in the property.Â  However, we recognized in Cannon that the thirty-nine acres of property acquired after the filing date but purchased with marital funds was nonmarital property as it did not exist at the time of filing.Â  Here, the family court found the First Citizens account was marital property.Â  Neither party challenges the determination that at least the initial deposit of funds was marital property.Â  Accordingly, it is the law of the case.Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 632, 576 S.E.2d 156, 166 (2003); Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 59, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
[6]We note that it does not appear in the record before us that the issue of tax debt was raised until Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  It is not clear when the revised tax liabilities were admitted into evidence, but it appears this may have occurred April 1, 2004 during the contempt hearing.Â  Husband did raise the issue in his motion to alter or amend.Â  However, as previously noted, there is no transcript from either the contempt hearing or from any hearing on Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend in the record.Â  Neither is there an order on the motion to alter or amend. Â 
[7]As an additional issue, Husband argues, assuming the family court correctly included his post-filing earnings and acquisition of new assets in the marital estate, the value of the marital estate should have been reduced by the entire amount of the tax obligation totaling $94,818.06 for the tax years 2000, 2001 and 2002.Â  In light of our disposition of these matters and, specifically, the remand to the family court on the post-earnings matter, we find it unnecessary to address this issue.
