text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, Respondent,
v.
Eric C. Salas, South Carolina Workerâ€™s Compensation Uninsured Employers Fund, Gannett Pacific Corporation, The Greenville News-Piedmont Company, and South Carolina Department of Revenue,
Defendants,
of whom Eric C. Salas is, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-177
Heard February 7, 2006 â€“ Filed March 29, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Randall S. Hiller, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Peter D. Korn, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this foreclosure action, Eric Salas appeals the masterâ€™s order denying his motion to set aside the default judgment entered against him and his motion to set aside the judicial sale of his Greenville County property.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On February 20, 2004, Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, Inc. (Wells Fargo) initiated a foreclosure action against Salas.Â  Salas failed to make payments to Wells Fargo on a note secured by a mortgage covering Salasâ€™s property in Greenville County (the Property).Â  Copies of the summons, complaint, and lis pendens were left with Salasâ€™s step-son, Joe Wigerman, at the Property address.Â  At the time, Wigerman was eleven or twelve years old.
On April 12, 2004, Wells Fargo filed an affidavit of default against Salas.Â  After a hearing, the master issued an order granting Wells Fargoâ€™s action to foreclose the mortgage and directing the sale of the Property at a public auction.Â  The order required that at the time of the sale the master obtain from the bidder a deposit of five percent of the amount of the bid.Â  The order also provided that if the bidder failed to comply with the terms of the sale within twenty days after the date of sale, the five percent deposit would be forfeited and applied to Salasâ€™s debt to Wells Fargo. 
At the judicial sale, the Property was sold to Family Home Solutions, LLC (Family Home).Â  Although the order required full compliance by September 21, 2004, Family Home did not fully comply until September 23, 2004â€”more than twenty days after the date of sale, but only two days after the set date for compliance.Â  Salas moved to set aside the default judgment and the sale of the Property.Â  The master denied both motions.Â  Salas appealed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The grant or denial of relief from a final judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-03 (1989).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the courtâ€™s order is controlled by an error of law or unsupported by the evidence.Â  Id.Â  An action to set aside a judicial property sale is equitable in nature.Â  Spillers v. Clay, 233 S.C. 99, 102, 103 S.E.2d 759, 760 (1958); Fed. Natâ€™l Mortgage Assâ€™n v. Brooks, 304 S.C. 506, 512, 405 S.E.2d 604, 607 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  In an equitable action, the appellate court may review the evidence to determine the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance evidence.Â  Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 248, 489 S.E.2d 472, 475 (1997).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Salas argues the master committed reversible error in denying his motions to set aside the default judgment and the judicial sale of the Property.Â  We disagree.Â  
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Set Aside Default JudgmentÂ  
Salas asserts the master erred in denying his motion to set aside the default judgment because service upon his step-son was improper.Â  We disagree.
Rule 4(d), SCRCP, provides service upon an individual must be made â€œby delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to him personally or by leaving copies thereof at his dwelling house or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing therein. . . .â€Â  The plaintiff carries the burden of showing that the trial court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant.Â  Jensen v. Doe, 292 S.C. 592, 594, 358 S.E.2d 148, 148 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  If the plaintiff complies with the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, however, proper service is presumed.Â  Fassett v. Evans, 364 S.C. 42, 47, 610 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Accordingly, an officerâ€™s return of process creates a legal presumption of proper service that cannot be impeached by the mere denial of service by the defendant.Â  Id.
Service was proper in this case.Â  After Wells Fargo filed an affidavit of service attesting to proper service upon a person of suitable age and discretion, the burden then shifted to Salas to show his step-son, Wigerman, was not a person of suitable age and discretion.Â  Salas introduced no evidence demonstrating Wigerman was not a person of suitable age and discretion.Â  Salas did not proffer Wigermanâ€™s testimony; he merely denied personally receiving the summons and complaint.Â  As Fassett makes clear, an officerâ€™s return of process creates a presumption of proper service that cannot be rebutted by Salasâ€™s mere denial of service by Wells Fargo.Â  Accordingly, the master did not abuse his discretion in denying Salasâ€™s motion to set aside the default judgment for improper service.Â Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Set Aside Sale of Property 
Salas next argues the judicial sale should be vacated or set aside because the successful bidder at the sale did not timely comply with the bid as required by the masterâ€™s order of foreclosure.Â  We disagree. 
The terms of sale, as set forth in the order of foreclosure and notice of sale, provide that the successful bidder must comply with the terms of the bid within twenty days of the close of the bidding process.Â  The terms of sale also provide that if the successful bidder does not comply within the twenty day period, the bidderâ€™s deposit will be forfeited and applied first to costs and then to Salasâ€™s debt.Â  In this case, it is undisputed that the successful bidder, Family Home, was two days late in paying the balance of its bid to the master.Â  The issue is whether this irregularity required the master to set aside the judicial sale of the Property. 
The terms of judicial sales are set by court order, Rule 71, SCRCP, and statute.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-39-10 to -900 (2005); Ex parte Moore v. Fairfield Real Estate Co., 352 S.C. 508, 510, 575 S.E.2d 561, 562 (2003); Ex parte Keller v. Hutto, 185 S.C. 283, 292-93, 194 S.E.2d 15, 18 (1937).Â  Bidders at judicial sales are charged with notice of the terms of sale and the selling officer has no authority to vary the terms set forth in the order of sale.Â  Hudson v. Inman, 179 S.C. 399, 404, 184 S.E.2d 102, 104 (1936).Â  Moreover, â€œalthough selling officers may not alter the terms of the court order, they are given wide discretion in the manner in which they conduct judicial sales.â€Â  Ex parte Moore, 352 S.C. at 510-11, 575 S.E.2d at 562.Â  Nevertheless, while case law makes clear that the â€œselling officer acts in a ministerial capacity as the arm of the courtâ€ and â€œin no way acts in a judicial capacity,â€ Fed. Natâ€™l Mortgage Assâ€™n v. Brooks, 304 S.C. 506, 510, 405 S.E.2d 604, 606 (Ct. App. 1991), in practice, the line between the selling and judicial functions has been blurred because the master may now serve in both capacities.Â  
A motion to vacate a judicial sale is equitable in nature and is addressed to the sound discretion of the court. Â Spillers v. Clay, 233 S.C. 99, 102, 103 S.E.2d 759, 760 (1958).Â  Courts are reluctant to set aside judicial sales on technical grounds.Â  Wooten v. Search, 187 S.C. 219, 223, 196 S.E. 877, 879 (1938).Â  The policy of our courts is to sustain a judicial sale when to do so does not violate principles of justice.Â  Cumbie v. Newberry, 251 S.C. 33, 37, 159 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1968); Brownlee v. Miller, 208 S.C. 252, 265, 37 S.E.2d 658, 663 (1946).Â  Thus, unless otherwise void, a judicial sale will not be set aside absent some special ground such as fraud, collusion, accident, mutual mistake, breach of trust, gross inadequacy of price, or misconduct on the part of the purchaser or selling officer.Â  Raleigh & C.R. Co. v. Ballentine Natâ€™l Bank, 41 F. Supp. 599, 601 (D.S.C. 1941); see also 47 Am. Jur. 2d Judicial Sales Â§ 359 (1995); 50A C.J.S. Judicial Sales Â§ 76 (1997).Â  Therefore, a judicial sale will not be set aside because of a mere irregularity in the proceedings of the sale, unless the party seeking to set aside the sale would be manifestly prejudiced by the irregularity.Â  Wooten, 187 S.C. 219 at 222, 196 S.E. at 878 (1938); 50A C.J.S. Judicial Sales Â§ 77 (1997). 
While there is a dearth of cases from this jurisdiction squarely on issue, in the case of Yates v. Gridley, 16 S.C. 496, 504 (1882), the court held that a bidder who was required to comply with his bid on the day of sale, but complied more than a month later, would not forfeit his bid in the absence of fraud or collusion after he had received title to the property.Â  Likewise, in the case of McFarlen v. Edwards, 456 So.2d 818, 819-20 (Ala. Civ. App. 1984), the court held that a ten day delay by the purchaser in paying the bid price was not such an irregularity to warrant setting aside the sale since the bidder testified he was able to pay cash on the day of sale.Â  
The guiding philosophy of our courts in deciding whether to interfere with a judicial sale is to determine whether the conduct of the sale was fair and regular so as to ensure the property was sold for the highest price obtainable.Â  Howell v. Gibson, 208 S.C. 19, 31, 375 S.E.2d 271, 276 (1946).Â  This is not a case where Salas claims misconduct on the part of the purchaser or that the selling officer chilled the bidding.Â  Thus, we look to the consequences of the late compliance to determine if Salas has been prejudiced.
Salas contends he is prejudiced by the lateness of the purchaserâ€™s compliance because if the deposit had been forfeited, and the property resold for the same sales price it sold for initially, most of the forfeited deposit would have been credited to his debt.Â  However, it is speculation on Salasâ€™s part that the property would have sold a second time for the same amount it sold for the first time.Â  Furthermore, it appears there were several secondary creditors of Salas who were entitled to any surplus that may have been generated from a resale of the property, though the amounts of their claims are not set forth in the record on appeal.
Accordingly, Salas has not shown how he was prejudiced by the late payment of the bid price, and will not be heard to complain of a mere irregularity that did not affect the fairness of the judicial sale.Â  Johnson Cotton Co. v. Cannon, 242 S.C. 42, 55, 129 S.E.2d 750, 757 (1963).Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
The trial courtâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charleston County Department of Social Services,
Respondent,
v.
Mother, Father, and Child, a child, born November 26, 1996,
Defendants,
Of Whom Mother and Father are the Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-178
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 31, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ilonka Sonja Taylor, Â of Charleston, for Mother.
Frank R. Warder, Jr., for Father.
FramptonÂ  Durban, Jr., of N. Charleston, for Respondent.
Margaret M. Urbanic, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM.:Â  This is an action for termination of the parental rights of the mother and the father to their biological child, a son born on November 26, 1996.Â  Both parents appeal.Â  We affirm.[1]
The Department of Social Services (DSS) instituted a protective services action on January 18, 2000, following allegations of sexual abuse by the father.Â  The family court placed the child in emergency protective custody on March 3, 2000, and, after hearing a removal action, prescribed a treatment plan for both the mother and the father.Â  Although the father never attended any counseling session, the mother completed the process.Â  As a result, the family court, following a review hearing on November 19, 2001, allowed her to take possession of her son, but enjoined her from allowing any unauthorized contact between the child and the father.Â  Several months later, on April 9, 2002, however, DSS determined unauthorized contact between the child and the father had occurred and removed the child from the motherâ€™s physical possession without resort to legal process.
In an order dated December 9, 2004, the family court found the best interests of the child required termination of the parental rights of both the mother and the father.Â  This followed findings that both the mother and father had willfully failed for a period in excess of six month to meet the conditions imposed by the court for them to visit the child and that the child had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  The family court also found the father had failed to remedy the conditions that caused the childâ€™s removal and had failed to support the child for a period in excess of six months.Â  After the family court denied the motherâ€™s post-trial motion to alter or amend, the mother and the father filed separate appeals.[2]
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s determination that the removal by DSS of the child on April 9, 2002, which took place with neither a court order nor the assistance of law enforcement, did not violate South Carolina Code sections 20-7-480 et seq. (Supp. 2005).Â  DSS already had â€œlegal custodyâ€ of the child by virtue of an earlier family court order dated December 10, 2001.Â  Although the latter order â€œplacedâ€ the child with the mother, it did not grant her legal custody of the child.[3]Â  Moreover, the family court in its December 10, 2001 order expressly authorized DSS â€œto take whatever action they [sic] deem necessary for the immediate health and welfare of the child.â€
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We do not address the argument made by DSS that any issue regarding the removal of the child on April 9, 2002, is moot.
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that DSS did not violate the motherâ€™s right to due process.Â  As noted above, the family court awarded DSS custody of the child in its order dated December 10, 2001.Â  Furthermore, the family court, as the record demonstrates, afforded the mother several opportunities to be heard on the issue of custody.Â  Indeed, the mother appeared with counsel in court no less than four times to contest the question of the childâ€™s custody.Â  On two of these occasions, she consented to the child remaining in the custody of DSS.[4]Â  Moreover, although the mother could have appealed a permanency planning order issued by the family court on January 31, 2003, she did not avail herself of this procedure.[5]
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We uphold the family courtâ€™s finding that DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence that the mother willfully failed to visit the child for a period in excess of six months when visitation was available to her upon satisfaction of reasonable conditions.Â  The record contains evidence to support this finding.[6]Â  The foster care worker assigned to the case testified agency rules required requests for visitation to be documented and she was unaware of any requests by the mother for visitation since April 9, 2002.
5.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The family court did not rule on the motherâ€™s argument questioning the constitutionality of South Carolina Code section 20-7-1572(8), which allows the termination of parental rights to serve the childâ€™s best interests if the child has been in State foster care for â€œfifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.â€[7]Â  Although the mother moved to alter or amend the judgment, her motion does not raise this issue.Â  Under these circumstances, this court cannot address the constitutionality of section 20-7-1572(8).[8]
6.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We further hold the family courtâ€™s application of section 20-7-1572(8) to terminate the motherâ€™s parental rights was proper notwithstanding the motherâ€™s remaining arguments, all of which concern numerous procedural delays and the lack of evidence of misconduct or parental unfitness on her part.Â  
Although several hearings scheduled after the childâ€™s second removal from the motherâ€™s home were continued, the postponements were ordered by the family court on its own motion.Â  There were no allegations that the delays resulted from dilatory tactics by DSS.Â  
As to the evidence concerning the motherâ€™s fitness as a parent, we find it significant that, whereas several of the other grounds for termination of parental rights require a finding of willful misconduct by the parent,[9] such a requirement is lacking in section 20-7-1572(8).Â  As this court recently stated, â€œthe purpose of [section 20-7-1572(8)] is to ensure children do not languish in foster care when termination of parental rights would be in their best interests.â€[10]Â  Because this section does not enumerate any factors that would militate against its application if the threshold requirement is satisfied, we hold the absence of fault on the parentâ€™s part cannot prevent its use as a ground for termination.[11]
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ. concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Counsel for the father filed an affidavit pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987).Â  In his affidavit, counsel stated he reviewed the existing transcript and, coupled with his recollection and knowledge of the proceedings, believed the appeal lacks merit. The father filed no response to counselâ€™s affidavit.Â  We have determined from our own review of the entire transcript that there exists no meritorious issue regarding the family courtâ€™s termination of the fatherâ€™s parental rights to the child in question that warrants briefing and dismiss the appeal as to the father.Â  
[3]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(21) (Supp. 2005) (defining the term â€œlegal custodyâ€ for the purposes of the Childrenâ€™s Code to mean, among other things, â€œthe right to the physical custody, care, and control of a childâ€ and â€œthe right to determine where the child shall liveâ€).Â  
[4]Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997) (â€œThe fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€).
[5]Â  See Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 291, 513 S.E.2d 358, 364 (1999) (â€œ[A]ny order issued as a result of a merit hearing, as well as any later order issued with regard to a treatment, placement, or permanent plan, is a final order that a party must timely appeal.â€) (emphasis added).Â  We recognize the motherâ€™s concern that the permanency planning order may not have been ripe for appeal because it was at least arguable that there had never been a full merits on the matter; however, such a serious procedural defect, if applicable, should have provided an even greater incentive for an appeal.
[6]Â  See Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E. 2d 541, 541 (1981) (noting the standard of review in equity cases â€œdoes not require [the appellate court] to disregard the findings below nor ignore the better vantage point the trial judge occupies in determining witness credibilityâ€).Â  
[7]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005).
[8]Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule on a question and the appellant fails to move under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals and should not be addressed).
[9]Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3) (Supp. 2005) (regarding the parentâ€™s failure to visit the child); id. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (regarding the parentâ€™s failure to support the child); id. Â§ 20-7-1572(9) (regarding physical abuse of the child by the parent); id. Â§ 20-7-1572(10) (providing as a ground of termination of parental rights an adjudication that the parent murdered the childâ€™s other parent).
[10] Charleston County Depâ€™t of Social Servs. v. Jackson, Op. No. 4090 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 6, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sheets at, 71, 84).Â  Unlike the parent is Jackson, the mother in the present case did not appeal the family courtâ€™s finding that termination of her parental rights was in the childâ€™s best interest.
[11] In Jackson, the court further held â€œit is the childâ€™s perspective, and not the parentâ€™s, that we are concerned with when determining whether [section 20-7-1572(8)] has been metâ€ and concluded â€œthe letter of the law was met once Child resided in foster for fifteen of the last twenty-two months regardless of Fatherâ€™s knowledge of Childâ€™s whereabouts.â€Â  Id. at 84. (emphasis added).Â  We note, however, this court in Jackson recognized â€œthere may be some instances where [section 20-7-1578(8)] would not support termination of parental rights despite the passage of a fifteen month stay in foster care.â€Â  Id. at 84 n.8 (quoting Justice Pleiconesâ€™s concurring opinion in S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 356 S.C. 413, 420, 589 S.E.2d 753, 756 (2003)).
